Forma parte del grupo solidario llamado Liliz 3. Con su préstamo invertirá en la compra de hilo al por mayor aumentando así la producción, y de esta forma contribuir al gasto familiar.

loans.use: Purchase thread

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is an artisan like many of the women of her community. She embroiders tablecloths, napkins, shawls, cushions, blouses, and she sells with the wholesalers in a nearby village. She is 35 years old, has six children, and is part of the group Lilz 3 together with Maria Sanchez Vazquez (another artisan). The loan will enable the wholesale purchase of thread.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

MARIA es artesana como muchas mujeres de su comunidad, borda manteles, servilletas, chales, cojines, blusas y lo vende con los mayoristas del pueblo más cercano. Ella tiene 35 años, seis hijos y forma parte del grupo llamado Liliz 3 junto con doña Maria Sánchez Vázquez (artesana). Con sus prestamos invertirán en la compra de hilo al por mayor.

loans.use: Purchase thread for embroidery work

loans.name: Matilde

texts.es:
Matilde is 34 years old and has two children. She is an artisan who makes tablecloths, napkins, cushions, shawls, blouses, and she sells them in a nearby town or in the city where the tourises buy traditional regional arts and crafts. She is part of the Neblina 3 group with two other artisans, Maria Pérez Pérez y Maria Martínez Pérez. With the loan they will invest in the purchase of various colored thread at wholesale prices.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

MATILDE tiene 34 años, dos hijos. Ella es artesana hace manteles, servilletas, cojines, chales, blusas y los vende en el pueblo mas cercano o en la ciudad en donde llegan turistas que compran artesanías típicas que caracterizan a cada pueblo. Forma parte del grupo llamado Neblina 3 junto con doña Maria Pérez Pérez (artesana) y doña Maria Martínez Pérez (artesana). Con la parte de sus prestamos invertirán en la compra de hilos en diversos colores al por mayor.

loans.use: Purchase thread

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is an artisan. She embroiders table clothes, napkins, cushions, blouses and the traditional clothing that women in her community wear. She sells her products in her town or in the city of San Cristobal de las Casas in the Santo Domingo Market. Her main clients are turists. She is 26 years old and has two children. She is a member of the group called Neblina 3, together with Mrs. Juana de la Cruz P. (artisan) and Mrs. Petrona Vazquez P. (artisan). With your loans they will buy thread wholesale and in this way increase the production of their embroideries.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

MARIA es artesana borda manteles servilletas, cojines, chales, blusas y ropa típica que las mujeres de su localidad utilizan y los vende en su pueblo o en la ciudad de San Cristóbal de las Casas en el Mercado de Santo Domingo, sus principales clientes son los turistas. Ella tiene 26 años, dos hijos. Forma parte del grupo llamado Neblina 3 junto con doña Juana de la Cruz Pérez (artesana) y doña Petrona Vázquez Pérez (artesana). Con sus prestamos compraran hilo al por mayor y de esta forma aumentaran la producción de sus bordados.

loans.use: Buying thread for embroideries

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is an artisan. She works in the manufacture and embroidering of tablecloths and napkins which she wholesales to people who later resell them in tourist zones. She is 24 years old, single, and with her income helps supplement her parent's living budget. She belongs to the MACOM 4 group along with doña Juana López López (Artisan) and doña Maria López Jiménez (Artisan). They will invest their loan in the purchase of large quantities of fabric for their handiwork as well as embroidery thread so that they can lower their overhead cost and profit a bit more on their later distribution.

Translated from Spanish by Eric Strader, Kiva Volunteer

MARIA, es artesana se dedica a la confección y bordado de manteles, servilletas y posteriormente los vende con personas mayoristas quienes las revenden en zonas turísticas, ella tiene 24 años es soltera y con sus ingresos ayuda al presupuesto familiar de sus padres, pertenece a l grupo MACOM 4 junto con doña Juana López López (Artesana) y doña Maria López Jiménez (artesana) Ellas invertirán su préstamo en comprar cantidades grandes de telas para sus prendas y además hilos para el bordado y así bajaran un poco el costo de compra al repartirse después lo comprado entre ellas

loans.use: Craftwork

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria is 34 years old, married, and has 7 childen. Her husband has a greenhouse and works selling flowers in the city of San Cristobal. She works in arts and crafts, and together with one of her daughters, Patrona P. P., makes table clothes and napkins and then they embroider them and sell them in Zinacantan, to the tourists visiting the area. They belong to the group Sabila 2, together with Mrs. Rosa Hernandez Gomez (artisan). With the loan they will buy cloth and thread to increase the production of their embroideries.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

MARIA, tiene 34 años, es casada tiene 7 hijos, su esposo tiene un invernadero trabaja vendiendo flores en la ciudad de San Cristóbal , ella se dedica a la artesanía y junto a una de sus hijas Patrona Pérez Pérez confeccionan manteles y servilletas y luego las bordan y venden en Zinacantan al turismo que visita la zona . Pertenecen al grupo Sábila 2 junto a doña Rosa Hernández Gómez (artesana). Con el préstamo compraran telas e hilos para aumentar cada una la producción de sus artesanías.

loans.use: cloth and thread for embroideries

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana is married, has 3 children and is 29 years old. Together with her husband she owns a locally conservatory dedicated to the cultivation of flowers. In addition, she involves herself in crafts and embroidery of tablecloths and blankets. She sells her products in the city closest to her community. She belongs to the Estrellas 1 group along with doña Juana Pérez López (Artisan). The wish to invest their loan in fabrics and thread for embroidering. Doña Juana will give additional help in the family business buying pesticides and fertilizers for the conservatory.

Translated from Spanish by Eric Strader, Kiva Volunteer

JUANA, es casada tiene 3 hijos y 29 años de edad, junto con su esposo tienen un invernadero ya que es una característica de la zona dedicarse al cultivo de las flores, además ella se dedica a la artesanía bordando manteles y mantas, venden sus productos en la ciudad mas cercana a su comunidad. Pertenece al grupo Estrellas 1 junto con doña Juana Pérez López (artesana). Esperan invertir el préstamo en telas e hilo para sus bordados y doña Juana apoyara además el negocio familiar comprando pesticidas y fertilizantes para su invernadero.

loans.use: Craftwork

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria works in the creation of art textiles and sells them to the wholesalers who visit her community. In addition, she helps her husband selling flowers. She is 31 years old, has 3 children, and belongs to the group Estrellas 1 together with Mrs. Maria P. Gomez (artisan) and Mrs. Catalina P. Hernandez (artisan). They will pool together their loans and buy cloth in great quantities and also embroidering thread wholesale, and then they will share the materials, thus increasing their income on the sale of their artwork.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

MARIA , se dedica a la confección de prendas artesanales y las vende a los mayoristas que visitan su comunidad además apoya a su esposo en la venta de flores , ella tiene 31 años , 3 hijos , pertenece al grupo Estrellas 1 junto con doña María Pérez Gómez (artesana) y doña Catalina Pérez Hernández (artesana). Ellas juntaran sus préstamos y compraran telas por cantidades grandes y también hilos de bordar en el mayoreo y después se las repartirán entre ellas obteniendo de esta forma más ganancias al vender sus artesanías.

loans.use: Buying cloth and embroidering thread.

loans.name: María De Los Ángeles

texts.es:
Maria de los Angeles thinks of herself as an enterprising person, devoted to her work and to her family. She is a very good salesperson, she is married and has two daughters. Her husband works in another general store. She decided to start her business to help her husband with the household expenses, and also to be able to offer her daughters education, and to save money and be able to leave a patrimony to her little ones. She has owned her business for one year and wants to grow with her business, increase her sales, and improve their quality of life.

Maria de los Angeles is asking for a loan for $750 to buy merchandise and to invest in a refrigerator to keep her products fresh and in consequence increase her business and have more clients. She offers to pay the loan in 6 months. She and her family thank you very much for your support in helping her be able to increase her business and reach her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

María de los Ángeles se considera una persona muy emprendedora, dedicada a su trabajo y a su familia, es una muy buena vendedora, ella esta casada y tiene 2 hijas, su esposo trabaja en otra tienda de abarrotes. Ella decidió poner su negocio para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar y también para poder brindarles educación a sus niñas y poder ahorrar y dejarles un patrimonio a sus pequeñas; ya tiene 1 año con el negocio y desea crecer con su negocio y poder ampliar sus ventas y mejorar su calidad de vida.

María de los Ángeles está solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 750 para comprar mercadería e invertir en la compra de un refrigerador para mantener sus productos frescos y con ello crecer y tener más clientes, ofreciendo pagar el préstamo en 6 meses. Ella y su familia te agradecen mucho tu apoyo para poder crecer con su negocio y lograr sus metas.

loans.use: Buying merchandise and a refrigerator for her store.

loans.name: Celia

texts.es:
Celia and her husband Walter have two children. Through a lot of effort and sacrifice in their work, they have built up their business of manufacturing and sale of caps and hats. This has allowed them to offer financial stability to their family, and more importantly an education to their children. They decided to work on this business 5 years ago, when Walter was unemployed after the business for which he worked went bankrupt. This event motivated both of them to start their own business in their humble home, manufacturing accessories to then offer them for sale while walking along a busy street in their town, Juliaca. They both have many projects and hopes and they are willing to work hard every day to make their plans reality. Celia's wish, for now, is to have more capital to invest in materials with the goal of creating their products with better finishes and being able to distribute them in large quantities. To make this wish come true, she is asking for a loan of $175. Celia and her family hope for your generous help.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Celia y su esposo Walter son padres de 2 hijos, que a costa de mucho esfuerzo y sacrificio en el desempeño de sus actividades pudieron constituir su negocio de confección y venta de gorros y sombreros, negocio con el que están ofreciendo estabilidad económica a su familia y lo más importante educación a sus hijos.Decidieron dedicarse a este negocio hace 5 años, cuando Walter quedó desempleado después que la empresa en la que trabajaba quebró; este hecho fue motivo suficiente para que ambos emprendan su propio negocio de fabricación de accesorios en su humilde domicilio, para luego ofrecerlos en forma ambulatoria en una calle concurrida de su localidad, Juliaca. Ambos tienen muchos proyectos e ilusiones y están dispuestos a esforzarse día a día para concretar sus planes. El deseo de Celia por el momento es contar con más capital de inversión para adquirir materia prima a fin de realizar la confección de sus productos con mejores acabados con el propósito de distribuirlos en grandes cantidades, para que este anhelo se haga realidad está solicitando un préstamo de 175 dólares..Celia y su familia esperan tu generosa colaboración.

loans.use: Buying materials for the manufacturing of their products.

loans.name: Antolina Rosa

texts.es:
Antolina is 32 years old and is an artisan, which is a typical vocation for women in her community who embroider articles with flowers of many colors. She embroiders tablecloths, napkins, and cushions and commercializes them in her villiage (Zinacantan). Her clients are tourists who visit and are captivated by the rich handiwork. She is part of the Estrellas 2 group along with Agustina Hernández Hernández (artisan) and doña Juana Hernández Hernández (artisan). With her loan she will purchase larger amounts of thread in a variety of colors.

Translated from Spanish by Eric Strader, Kiva Volunteer

ANTOLINA tiene 32 años y es artesana, característica de las mujeres de su comunidad que bordan las prendas con flores de diversos colores. Ella borda manteles, servilletas, chales, cojines y los comercializa en su pueblo (Zinacantan) cuyos clientes son turistas que visitan el lugar y son cautivados por la riqueza artesanal. Forma parte del grupo llamado Estrellas 2 junto con Agustina Hernández Hernández (artesana) y doña Juana Hernández Hernández (artesana). Con sus prestamos compraran hilo al por mayor en variedad de colores.

loans.use: Craftwork

loans.name: Sebastiana

texts.es:
Sebastiana is 40 years old and has three children. She and her husband are merchants; they sell fruits and vegetables to other communities far from their hometown. They have a van that lets them travel and transport their merchandise from one place to another. Sebastiana is part of the solidarity group called Crisantema 1. With your loan she will increase the investement in fruits and vegetables which will allow them to visit more communities and increase their income, thus improving the financial situation of their family.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

SEBASTIANA tiene 40 años y tiene tres hijos. Ella junto con su esposo son comerciantes, se dedican a vender frutas y verduras a otras comunidades lejanas a su lugar de origen, tienen una camioneta que les permite viajar y transportar la mercancía de un lugar a otro. Forma parte del grupo solidario llamado Crisantema 1. Con su préstamo aumentara la inversión de frutas y verduras lo cual permitirá que visiten más comunidades y así obtendrán mas ganancias que les permitirá mejorar su condición económica familiar.

loans.use: Buying merchandise (fruits and vegetables)

loans.name: Sebastiana

texts.es:
Sebastiana has done craftwork since she was very young like the majority of the women in her community. She is 45 years old, has six children, and her spouse is a floriculturalist (sowing of flowers, especially roses). About a year and a half ago she suffered an embolism that affected half of her body, and since that time she has not been able to embroider. Now, she deals in fabric which she distributes to other women who embroider it to create the finished product to sell in Santo Domingo . She is part of the Crisantema 1 group.

Translated from Spanish by Eric Strader, Kiva Volunteer

SEBASTIANA ha sido artesana desde muy pequeña al igual que la mayoría de las mujeres de su comunidad. Ella tiene 45 años, siete hijos y su esposo se dedica a la floricultura (siembra de flores, especialmente rosas). Hace aproximadamente año y medio ella sufrió una embolia afectando la mitad de su cuerpo, desde entonces no ha podido bordar, ahora ella compra la tela y paga a otras mujeres para que borden las prendas obteniendo de esta forma el producto terminado y lo vende en Santo Domingo. Forma parte del grupo Crisantema 1.

loans.use: Craftwork

loans.name: Rosa Victoria

texts.es:
ROSA VICTORIA is 23 years old and has two children. She is craftswoman who embroiders napkins, tablecloths, cushions, and shawls; she also buys goods from other women and sells them in the local market in Santo Domingo in the city of San Cristóbal. Her main customers are tourists who visit the area. She is a member of an association called Cristantema 1. With the loan she will buy wholesale linen in a variety of colors as well as other goods that is no longer in her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

ROSA VICTORIA tiene 23 años, dos hijos. ElL. es artesana borda servilletas, manteles, cojines, chales, también compra el producto terminado D. otras mujeres y los venD. en el local que tiene en el mercado D. Santo domingo D. L. ciudad D. San Cristóbal, sus principales clientes son turistas que visitan el lugar. Forma parte del grupo solidario llamado Crisantema 1. Con su préstamo invertirá en L. compra D. hilo al por mayor en su variedad D. colores y en L. compra D. mercancía terminada.

loans.use: for craftwork

loans.name: Margarita Estrella

texts.es:
Sisters IRIS IZAMAL and MARGARITA are single. Their parents are merchants and work hard to sell fruit and vegetables in various communities. They are in charge of housekeeping. They've decided that with the loan, they will sell fruits and vegetables in their home and buy products at the most competitive prices in their locale. They will also buy a stand for the fruits and vegetables, bags and a scale. They are part of an association called Crisantema 1.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

IRIS IZAMAL y MARGARITA son solteras y son hermanas. Sus padres son comerciantes, se dedican a vender frutas y verduras llevando a distintas comunidades. Ellas se quedan a cargo del hogar y por lo tanto decidieron con su préstamo establecer en su casa la venta de frutas y verduras comprando los productos mas cotizados por su localidad, un exhibidor para la mercancía, bolsas y una bascula. Forman parte del grupo llamado Crisantema 1.

loans.use: Buy fruits and vegetables to sell them

loans.name: Rosa Heraclia

texts.es:
The bravery that Rosa has demonstrated when faced with failures has helped her overcome them gracefully. To successfully fulfill the basic needs of her family in all the activities that they do, she opened a small store in her house two years ago. She had to sacrifice the development of the store because of her constant health problems caused by a uterine fibroma. Not long after finding out about the fibroma, she had to undergo surgery in a local clinic in order to save her life. Rosa is mother to 4 children and now only the youngest, who is 13 years old, is in her care. For this reason she wants to continue to strive. At present she is in better physical and financial condition and she has been able to find work lending small amounts of money to her neighbors, which allows her to buy certain necessities to support her family. Nonetheless, she longs to once again open her little store in order to lend her services and satisfy the needs of the general public. For this reason she is requesting a loan of $350, which will be the first step in her effort to see her dream succeed. We support a woman who can overcome any obstacle with bravery. With your help you will be able to do that, too.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Westin, Kiva volunteer.

La valentía que demostró ante los fracasos le ha servido a Rosa para salir siempre airosa de cada una de ellas y a poder satisfacer exitosamente las necesidades primarias de su familia con cada una de las actividades que ha desempeñado, hace dos años abrió una pequeña tienda en su casa y tuvo que sacrificar su desarrollo por sus constantes problemas de salud debido a un fibroma en el útero, a poco tiempo de sucedido este hecho tuvo que ser operada en una clínica de su localidad para salvar su vida. Ella es madre de 4 hijos y ahora sólo la menor de trece años se encuentra en su poder, razón por la que aún desea continuar esforzándose. Actualmente se encuentra mejor física y económicamente y ha podido encontrar una muy buena ocupación realizando préstamos pequeñísimos a sus vecinos que le permiten obtener ciertas utilidades para sostener a su familia; sin embargo anhela abrir una vez más su pequeña tienda para prestar sus servicios y satisfacer las necesidades del público en general. A razón de este hecho solicita un préstamo de 350 dólares que se convertirá en el primer escalón de progreso para continuar con este deseo. Apoyemos a una mujer que con valentía vence cualquier obstáculo. Con tu colaboración podrás hacerlo.

loans.use: To create a small grocery store in her home

loans.name: Faauliuli

texts.en: Faauliuli joined Vaovai Centre in May, 2005. She is 48 years old and married with six grown-up children. All her life she has been a housewife, which is a role she felt happy in, and was honored to serve her family. However, having six children and only relying on her husband to feed them was very hard. Faauliuli and her family used to live on their taro plantation. With her first loan, she bought chemical, fertilizers, knives, and a back sprayer. This will be Faauliuli's 3rd loan with SPBD, and she has always felt privileged to have this opportunity to develop her business and upgrade her family’s living conditions. She is hoping that she will be able to expand her shop in the future and to add a store in front her home.

loans.use: To restock her shop and to buy a freezer to store soft drinks

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Tepora Tolumai

texts.en: Tepora is a married mother who is 28 years old. She has two children and her husband is unemployed. They used to live on their plantation, which Tepora's husband looked after. Through their hard work they have made small improvements for their family. They now own a taxi which really helps with transportation, and in helping to carry the taro from their village to sell in the market. This is Tepora's second loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To buy 5 liters of gromoxome chemicals, a back sprayer, and other equipment needed for her plantation.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Claudia Margarita

texts.es:
Claudia is a brave woman who goes out each and finds ways to sell nutritious goods like raw honey, cheese, and sometimes, trouts to delight the Huancaya citizens' palates. However, for these aforementioned sales, she also receives a lot of commission. For three years, she has been able to more than meet her target and has had plentiful income for her living expenses. She has taken her young son along to the city to sell these products. She travels every fifteen days to the capital city with the intention of making successful sales as well as doing some embroidery, which she started a little while ago. This activity also generates some additional income to meet the lifestyle she is used to. Since she has her young son to support, she wishes to set up a store to take care of him like a good mother ought to. If she does this, she envisions a brighter future for her family. Thus, she seeks a loan of $275 to invest in more merchandise so she can sell and make greater profits. In this way, she will be able to save and realize her dream sooner. Your generosity will be like soothing honey to this sweet mother's anxieties.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Claudia es una mujer valerosa que cada día trabaja de manera independiente en la venta de productos alimenticios como la miel de abeja, quesos y a veces truchas para el deleite de los paladares huancaínos. Sin embargo por la comercialización del primer producto que les mencionamos recibe muchos más réditos y hace trece años ha podido satisfacer las necesidades de su hogar plenamente, en compañía de su ultimo retoño recorre la ciudad para vender sus productos. Así mismo viaja cada quince días a la ciudad capital de su país con el propósito de realizar sus ventas también en este lugar, de manera adicional ha iniciado hace poco el bordado de fustanes y esta actividad le está generando un ingreso adicional para incrementar el nivel de vida familiar. Como buena madre que es anhela establecerse en un local por el cuidado que tiene que brindarle a su pequeño hijo. Así mismo ve con mucho optimismo su futuro a lado de su amada familia, es por ello que solicita un préstamo de 275 dólares con el fin de invertirlos en la compra de más artículos con el propósito de obtener mayores ganancias y de esa manera ahorrar y hacer realidad su anhelo en corto tiempo.Usted podrá hacer que la miel de su generosidad satisfaga las ansias de esta dulce madre.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise to eventually be able to set up her own store

loans.name: Fatufua

texts.en: Fatufua comes from a family of five, She is 37 years of age, married, and has two children. Her family has been living on their plantation, which was their only source of income. Through years of hard work, they have improved their lives and managed to increase the size of their plantation. This is Fatufua second year with SPDB and this will be her second loan. In the future, Fatufua is planning to export her taro overseas and to renovate her home.

loans.use: To buy equipment for her taro plantation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Pereta

texts.en: P. comes from a poor family of 12 people. They were poor enough so that sometimes their mother could not afford to send them to school. She is now 32 years old, married, and has five children of her own. She has experienced the difficulties of family life, as she does not have a job to support the family. Her husband is a hard working man and they have put all their effort and time into their plantation. Through days of working in the sun and sometimes in the rain, P. and her husband renovated their home. Through her previous loan she has installed a water supply. This is P.'s second loan, and she is planning to buy a water tank because the water supply in her area is very poor. Sometimes they hardly get water, so most of the time they rely on the rain water.

loans.use: To buy gromoxone chemicals (weed killer), a back sprayer, fertilizers, and a wheelbarrow for her plantation as well as a water tank.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Félix

texts.es:
Félix is a father and for many years, he has been able to fulfill his responsibilities and financially support his family and provide for his children's education. Today, he is content to see that his sons have been brought up in a proper way. He was able to support his children by selling books after some failures in the transportation sector. With time and his diligence, he was able to start his own store near the city center and currently, his store sells a wide range of textbooks for students in his region. He also supports his aging, sick mother and also has his nephew under his care.

His love towards his family motivates him. He awaits the day in which he can return to his native region Churcampa to live the rest of his old age there. He is empowered to save for his future and therefore, seeks a loan of $100 to invest in more books, with the purpose of making higher profits to support his nephew and be a good-doer. Endorse Félix in his patriarchal efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Don Félix es un padre de familia que durante largos años ha sabido cumplir responsablemente con su deber y les brindó abrigo, comida y educación a sus hijos y hoy observa con satisfacción la correcta forma con la que se conducen sus hijos dentro de su ciudad. Él logró sostener a sus hijos con la venta de libros tras sufrir varios fracasos en el área de transporte, con el tiempo gracias a su diligencia ha logrado obtener un propio local de ventas cerca del centro de su ciudad y en la actualidad ofrece una inmensa variedad de textos para la estudiosa población de su localidad con el propósito de sostener económicamente a su anciana madre que se encuentra delicada de salud y a un sobrino en su poder.

Motivado por el amor que siente hacia su familia, anhela poder volver a su tierra natal Churcampa para radicar y vivir su vejez allí. Con el ánimo de ahorrar para cumplir su deseo solicita un préstamo de 100 dólares para invertirlos en la compra de más libros con el objetivo de generar mayores ganancias para apoyar a su sobrino y hacerlo un hombre de bien. Apoya a Don Félix en su labor paternal.

loans.use: Compra de libros.

loans.name: Mele

texts.en: Mele is a 49-year old mother of five children. She is married and joined SPBD two years ago. She heard about the program through her fellow villagers, and she decided to join. Mele and her family have been living on their plantation, which is their main source of income, for a long time. This is Mele's 3rd loan with SPBD and she believes the financial support she has been receiving has allowed her family to make ends meet. They have renovated their home. Mele is planning to export her taro overseas which she believes will generate a great source of extra income.

loans.use: To buy gromoxone chemicals (weed killer), fertilizers, wheelbarrow, and other supplies for her plantation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Elsa Loyda

texts.en:
With creativity and cleverness, Elsa was able to get into the business of manufacturing shoes for artistic shows. It all started 19 years ago, when she and her husband began repairing shoes for her neighbors. She learned this noble profession from her husband, whom also acquired the skills from his family. Today, they believe they have been successful since they were able to open a location that allows them to support their five children. Their willingness to keep their family together, has motivated them to keep working hard, fulfilling all the manufacturing orders and not just repairing them. With their dressmaking skills, they supplement their business by making fashionable suits. Their small store has been growing steadily, always with the purpose of improving the quality of their clothes. She is asking for a loan of US$175 that will be invested in buying more supplies for their small tailoring business. Let’s support a family that wishes to continue tailoring their noble dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Gabriel Santamaria, Kiva Volunteer.

Con creatividad e ingenio, Elsa, logró incursionar en la fabricación de zapatos para espectáculos artísticos. Todo comenzó hace 19 años cuando en una esquina de su barrio ella y su esposo empezaron a arreglar los zapatos de sus vecinos, este oficio digno lo aprendió de su esposo quién también obtuvo esta enseñanza de su familia y hoy se sienten satisfechos porque han podido establecerse en un local que les permite sostener a sus cinco hijos El deseo de mantener a su familia siempre unida la impulsa a seguir trabajando con diligencia, cubriendo pedidos de fabricación y ya no sólo reparándolos; con sus conocimientos de costura complementa el traje de las prendas para los espectáculos y su pequeño negocio ha ido creciendo notablemente siempre con el propósito de mejorar la calidad de sus prendas. Solicita un préstamo de 175 dólares que los invertirá en la compra de más insumos para su pequeño taller de confección. Solidaricémonos con una familia que anhela seguri confeccionando sus nobles sueños.

loans.use: Buying supplies for manufacturing fashionable clothing.

loans.name: Luafata

texts.en: Luafata is 42 years old, married, and has five children. She joined SPBD in 2006, with the intention of getting financial assistance. She is a poor mother who has always believed in hard work. Luafata used to work but when she got married and had her first child, she decided to stay home, which greatly affected her family life. She heard about SPBD’s loans last year, and so she decided to join. Since then, she had upgraded many things in her home. She has been selling ice cakes to the school nearby, and she is also making pancakes as a second back-up business. Luafata is planning to run a proper canteen where she could sell other things to the school children and also the village people.

loans.use: To renovate her home and to buy supplies for her Ice Cake selling business .

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en: Telesia is a single mother of 22 years of age, supporting a 2-month old child. She is the second youngest from a family of 7 brothers and 5 sisters. Telesia's father passed away when she was only 5 years old, so she was raised by her aunt. They were so poor that her adopted mother could not afford to send her to school. She has struggled her whole life, so when she had her own child, she decided to join SPBD. This is Telesia's third loan, and she managed to build herself a small island house. She is doing very well with her business and attracting many customers everyday.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her Ice Cake shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Veronika

texts.en: Veronika is 41-years-old, married, and has six children. Veronika and her husband have been tending a vegetable garden for more than two years. This is their main source of income and from their garden, they have increased their standard of living. She heard about SPBD’s loans through the other women of the village. She feels privileged for the opportunity given to her by SPBD. She sells her vegetable twice or three times a week at the market. Her husband recently bought a taxi, so it has become easier to deliver their crops to the market. In the future, Veronika is planning to build herself a mini-market in front her home so she can sell her vegetables there. It will save them money on the cost of delivery and will be easier for them to maintain her crops.

loans.use: To buy cabbage seeds, wheelbarrow, fertilizers, and other supplies for her vegetable garden.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Etevise

texts.en: Etevise is 32-years-old, married, and has six children. Her parents have had a vegetable garden for ages, and now Etevise has taken over. Her husband is a very hard-working man, and he has been working on the garden for a long time. Through years of hard work, they have managed to improve their family life. Etevise is thankful for the financial support from SPBD, especially since her husband is unemployed and their six children need looking after. She sells enough every week to make a profit, and she is planning to buy a car to use in delivering her vegetables, not only to the market but to the village as well.

loans.use: To buy a back sprayer, fertilizers, gromoxone chemical (weed killer), knives, and a spade for her garden.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Vaeula

texts.en: Vaeula is a married mother of 29 years of age. She has five children, and helps support five other relatives. Her family lives on proceeds from their vegetable garden, which is their main source of income. Her father is a carpenter and he works when he can. Vaeula and her family have worked hard on their garden, which has many different types of vegetables. This will be Vaeula’s second loan. With her first loan, she bought gardening equipment and supplies. Recently, along with her husband, she has built their own place to live and renovated it. Vaeula is planning to expand her family farm and to further improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To buy back sprayer, fertilizers, spade and gromoxone chemical (weed killer) for her vegetable garden.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Edith Janeth

texts.es:
Edith is a young mother with four children who are her reason for living. It is for them why she works daily untiringly selling prepared foods, which she does after the recommendation from her friend after observing her talent and the exquisite seasoning she had. She decided to implement her little business in order to offer the immense variety in the dishes that she prepares with delicacy and patience. Shortly after having started her project she was the victim of a theft that stripped her of all her work tools. However difficult the circumstance this didn't break her spirits, and still saw her culinary future with optimism. She decided to initiate again, but with certain restrictions given that she has no account with a sufficient amount of money to purchase again what the thieves stole from her, and maintain in rout her wish to reopen her little dream with more force than before.

In order to fulfill her intention she asks those who share the common interest with the purpose of receiving their support to obtain a loan of $350 USD. This would be used to to acquire utensils for cooking and some small devices for added performance. Let us offer to her our support so that this valiant mother continues cooking and fulfilling the dreams of her family with love.

Translated from Spanish by James Lombardo, Kiva Volunteer.

Edith es una joven madre de cuatro hijos que son su razón de vivir; por ellos trabaja día a día incansablemente vendiendo comidas preparadas a recomendación de una amiga suya al observar atentamente el talento y la exquisita sazón que tenía. Decidió implementar su pequeño negocio para ofrecer la inmensa variedad de platos que prepara con delicadeza y paciencia; a poco tiempo de haber puesto en marcha su proyecto sufrió un robo que la despojó de todas sus herramientas de trabajo. Sin embargo esta difícil circunstancia no la desanimó y aún observa su futuro culinario con optimismo. Ha decidido iniciar una vez más pero con ciertas restricciones debido a que no cuenta con el dinero suficiente para reponer lo que se llevaron los ladrones y mantiene aún en pie su deseo de reabrir su pequeño sueño con más fuerza que antes,

para cumplir su propósito acude a aquellos corazones solidarios con el fin de recibir su apoyo para obtener en calidad de préstamo la suma de 350 dólares que le servirán para adquirir utensilios de cocina y algunos artefactos pequeños en pro de su buen desempeño. Brindémosle nuestro apoyo para que esta valerosa madre siga cocinando los sueños de su familia con amor.

loans.use: Buy cooking utensils

loans.name: Vaoesea

texts.en: Vaoesea, from the village of Saanapu, never has a moment to spare. The 36 year old mother of four children runs a small business to support her family.  Her grocery shop helps to support her husband’s taro plantation so they’re able to put their children through school and improve their living standards.  Her weekly earnings, after all expenses, is $120, and the three sacks of taro her husband sells at Fugalei market every weekend provides the family with extra profits of $120.

loans.use: Home improvement and the expansion of her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Fatilua

texts.en: Fatilua, 33 years old, has a talent for printing elei (screen printing on elei materials).  She purchases yards of material of various colours and prints on them.  In order to make ends meet and to feed and clothe her four kids, Fatilua has made full use of her talent.  By delivering to the village shops and catering at a stall at the flea market five times a week, she earns a profit of $50 per day after expenses, giving her enough to put food on the table and to make her weekly loan repayment to SPBD.

loans.use: For home improvement and for supplies and materials for her elei printing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sera

texts.en: Sera is a hard-working woman that tends to her taro plantation every day of the week.  She is able to sell two full sacks of taro at the Fugalei market every Saturday.  She does not mind the half-hour trip from Saanapu into town because she knows there is always a high demand for her products.  Her business earns her a profit of $130 weekly after all expenses, which keeps her family going through hard times.  It also gives her a chance to receive further loans from SPBD, which allows her to keep her business going strong.

loans.use: To expand her plantation by buying supplies and equipment

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Aniva

texts.en: A. is a 37 year old mother of two, who struggles to make ends meet financially.  This is mainly due to the fact that her husband doesn’t earn much as a bus driver.  However, Anivas' determination to satisfy her family needs drove her to start up her screen printing elei business. She borrowed from SPBD to purchase all materials needed to start up.  She sells to the locals and some tourists passing through her village of Safaatoa Uta.  This helps her to earn $120 a week after all expenses.  She is now able to help her husband with his weekly earnings of $120.

loans.use: For home improvement and for supplies for her elei screen printing business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Naoafioga

texts.en: Naoafioga struggles financial because of her weekly family, village, and church commitments. She helps to supports her extended family, and she has one child of her own. Her grocery shop opens seven days a week and caters to her fellow villagers. Her long shop hours extend from 6am to 8pm daily. Because of the excellent service she offers to her customers (competitive prices, abundant supply, and good quality), her increasing sales earns her a profit of $150 a week. She is now able to satisfy all of her commitments.

loans.use: To expand her shop by buying supplies and inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Vitoria works on her plantation daily while also being a full time mother. She is 21 years old and her determination to give her child a good education and good living conditions drives her to work hard to earn extra money. Her husband is a full time professional carpenter who does contract work that earns him a net of $200 a week. With the cost of living going up every day, it is very important for both of them to work. Therefore Vitoria tends and maintains her taro plantation so that her husband can sell two sacks every Saturday, which earns a profit of $120. She is now able to look after her family and make her loan repayments to SPBD, which allows her to take future loans.

loans.use: For home improvement and to expand her shop buy buying supplies and inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Selesitina

texts.en: Selesitina is a 37 year old lady, married, and has four children. She is a very diligent in her family and community commitments, and is well-known for her community fundraising efforts. Her plantation is her biggest source of income and she works really hard at it. Her first loan was used to buy some chemicals and fertilizers for her plantation and cement, timber, and iron roofs for  home improvement. She hopes that her next loan will be used to add to her vegetable garden business to back up her existing plantation. She is very happy and appreciates SPBD’s loan program. She hopes to keep taking future loans for a long time to come.

loans.use: For home improvement

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Firangiz

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice has always dreamed of seeing her children well educated, but this dream was almost shattered since she and her husband could not afford school fees.  This caused her to obtain a loan from GHAPE to start a business.  She has since successfully invested four loans and has been able to sponsor some of her children through secondary school.

With a loan of $1000, she plans to invest in her former business of selling groundnuts and also start selling ready-made dresses.  She plans to use the profit to further pay school fees for her children.

She plans to pay her loan in 24 months.  The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Pay rent and start sale of ready-made dresses

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Born in 1975, Comfort is married and is a mother of three children all below the age of 15.  

Her husband’s meager salary not being sufficient to provide for all of the family's needs, she decided to request a loan from GHAPE to start a business.  She has been able to manage and invest loans of more than $200, with which she embroidered dresses and sold them.  The profit was used to buy food for her family.

With a loan of $200, she plans to invest in the same line of business and add to it the sale of palm oil.  Embroidered dresses are worn by notables, especially during traditional occasions.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months.  The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement.

loans.use: Invest in her business of embroidered dresses and add sale of palm oil

loans.name: Rafiga

texts.en: Rafiga and her husband have been running a chicken farming business for three years.  She is 43 years old and lives in Khachmaz town and has one child.  They raise chicken and then sell them. They are requesting a loan of $825 to buy chickens for their business.

loans.use: To buy chicken for their poultry farming business

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret A.’s husband, Tita Zacharia has been sick for a long time and she has spent the little money she had trying to get him cured to no avail.  Presently, she is the sole provider for her six children and her husband.  As a hard working woman, she grates cassava and fries it to get what is locally called "garri", which she then sells in wholesale and retail.  Garri is consumed either with soup or in cold water with sugar added.

With a loan of $300, she plans to increase the garri quantity she produces so she can have more income.  The profit will be used to buy food for her family and to pay school fees for her children.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months.  Her first loan repayment installment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Production and sale of Garri

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph T. is a father of five children and the husband of Longla Lucien.  As a father, he has always worked hard to see that his children get an education.  This wish could not be acheived because his business of rearing pigs was not giving him much profit as he was not able to invest enough in it.

As a new member of GHAPE, and with a new loan of $100, he plans to fatten and sell pigs and use the profit to pay school fees for his children.

He will repay the loan in 12 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of piglets and pig feed to expand his business

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is a single mother of one child.  She was abandoned by her husband due to a marital misunderstanding.  Presently, she feeds herself and her family from the small income she gets from her knitting business.  However, she also has the responsibility of providing for her relatives.

With a loan of $100, she plans to increase her knitting business and sell her sweaters in schools and nurseries.  She also plans to fabricate and sell yogurt to local primary school pupils.

The profit will be used to provide basic needs for her family and pay school fees for her daughter who is in secondary school.

loans.use: Invest in and expand her knitting business

The R. family lives in Khudat town, in the Khachmaz region. Ali is 50 years old, married and has five children. Four  years ago he started his own business.   He has a lot of regular clients. All come to his café to forget their problems.
He is requesting a loan of $825  to buy  glasses and other necessary things for his cafe.

loans.name: Adila

texts.en: Adila, 49 is a widow with one child. She lives in Khachmaz town and has a business selling shoes to retail stores/shops. Adila has three years of experience in this business. She is requesting a loan of $725 to buy more inventory for ressale.

loans.use: To buy shoes for resale

loans.name: Gafar

texts.en: Gafar, 64 lives in Khachmaz town and has three children.  He has his own business - an orchard where he grows pomegranate. He has been in this business for three years. He now needs a loan of $725 to buy pesticides for improving his yield.

loans.use: To buy pesticides to improve his yield

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en: Gulnara, 49 is  a widow with six children. She lives in Khachmaz town. She purchases cooking utensils ( pans, frying-pans and etc.) and sells them to shops. She has been doing this for three years. She now needs a loan of $725 to buy more goods for resale.

loans.use: To  buy untensils for resale

loans.name: Bahram

texts.en: Bahram lives  in Khachmaz  town and has been runhing his farming business for 3 years. He is 49 years old, married and has three children. . He is requesting a loan of $725 to buy pesticides.

loans.use: Loan to purchase pesticides for his farming business

loans.name: Louise

texts.en:
This loan will be shared by seven women from the village of Ker Gu Mag in northern Senegal. The group submitted the following loan application:

“Our region has no industrial infrastructure, and if you consider that everyone in rural areas like our own has suffered from land desertification, you will understand why marketing local crops is so important for improving food security. The local women's credit associations lack the financial resources to meet this challenge on their own.

Our group aims to buy, process, and sell local food products, in order to increase the earnings of our members. We will travel to markets in surrounding villages to buy sorghum, millet, bissap [a type of hybiscus, of which the leaves and flowers are widely used in Senegalese cooking] and baobab fruit, and resell them in villages where they are in high demand. The loan will allow our group to ensure the availability of these foods, which are often scarce in our village."

Original French business description:

«La région se particularise surtout par l’absence d’infrastructures industrielles et quand on sait que les conséquences de la désertification n’épargnent plus aucune couche sociale de la région qui est une zone rurale ; on comprend mieux pourquoi la transformation des céréales locales devient une activité capitale pour le monde rural toujours confronté au défi de la sécurité alimentaire. Les coopératrices au nombre de 2339 membres souffrent le plus souvent de la rareté des ressources financières.

L’objectif : Achat, vente et transformation de produits locaux. Aider à renforcer les activités de transformation de produits locaux et encourager le petit commerce.

Objectif spécifique : Appuyer les femmes membres à bien assurer leurs propres activités ; Bref description des activités à mener avec le prêt :

-Acheter les produits locaux dans les loumas de la région et les revendre soit après transformation ou sans transformation suivant l’attraction des prix du moment.

- Pour le volet transformation des produits locaux ; les femmes membres spécialisées s’en chargeront dans leur unité de transformation et les produits revendus pour accroître les revenus des membres. »

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural micro-enterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance. Visit our website at www.sem-fund.org to learn more!

loans.use: Purchase of local grains and food products for resale in village market

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance Fund (SEM) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Khadijatou

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the four women of the Mankko group, led by Ms. Khadijiatou D.. In their loan application, the group describe their business as follows:

“Our business is located in the outskirts of Dakar, in the Parcelles Assainies neighborhood. It is composed of an association of women who have been engaged in petty trading for a long time. Our goal is to improve the living conditions of our members, contribute to the well-being of our families, and help the parents in our group to educate their daughters. The business will consist of buying different types of cloth and reselling them in the other towns and regions of Senegal.”

Original French business description:

«Contexte: Le projet se situ dans la banlieue de Dakar plus précisément aux parcelles Assainies. Il regroupe une association de femmes qui s’exercent dans le commerce depuis un bon bout de temps.

Objectifs: Améliorer les conditions de vies des populations composantes le dit groupement; Contribuer à la gestion et à l’entretien des problèmes familiaux; Aider les parents sur la scolarisation des jeunes filles.

Activités: Il s’agit d’acheter des tissus et aller les revendre dans les autres villes et régions du Sénégal.»

Background:

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance. Visit our website at www.sem-fund.org to learn more!

loans.use: Purchase of cloth for resale in markets

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance Fund (SEM) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the ten women of the Sop Naby group, led by Ms. Adama M.. In their loan application, the group describe their business as follows:

“Our business is located in the region of Fatick, in the village of Ndiaye Ndiaye. It is composed of women who are united around a common ideal. Our goal is to help women strengthen their existing skills, combat youth employment and female migration, and improve the lives of our members. The business will consist of retail trading of local foods.”

Original French business description:

«Contexte: Le projet se situ dans la région de Fatick et à l’éco village de Ndiaye Ndiaye. Il regroupe des femmes unies autour d’un même idéal.

Objectifs: Le groupement se fixe comme objectif d’aider les femmes dans leurs domaine de compétence; De lutter contre le chômage des jeunes et l’exode des femmes; D’améliorer les conditions de vie des membres du groupements.

Activités: Le groupement s’est fixé comme activité: Le commerce. Il s’agit d’achat et de vente de produits de consommation local .»

Background:

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance. Visit our website at www.sem-fund.org to learn more!

loans.use: Purchase and production of local foods for sale in town market

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance Fund (SEM) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mariana

texts.es:
Mariana is married to a taxi driver, and they have one son. She is a very hard-working woman, and she decided to undertake her own business because she wanted to help her husband with the family finances. His income was very low and many times was not enough to support the family. Two years ago, Mariana started selling meals to a school, and little by little, she has made herself know and has improved her business. Presently she has a steady clientele of thirty people each week and also sells food to a construction company near her house.

Mariana is requesting a loan of $250 to be able to buy a larger table and bigger pots so she can expand her business. She is offering to repay the loan in three months. She and her family thank you for the support that you provide them so they can continue growing their business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer.

Mariana esta casada y su esposo es taxista, ellos tienen un hijo, ella es una mujer muy trabajadora y decidió emprender su propio negocio por que quiso ayudar a su esposo en la economía familiar, ya que los ingresos de su esposo eran muy bajos y muchas veces no les alcanzaba para el sustento, entonces ella hace dos años atrás empezó vendiendo comidas para una escuela y poco a poco se ha hecho conocida y a mejorado su negocio, ya que en la actualidad ella tiene una clientela fija de 30 personas por semana y además vende a una constructora que esta cerca de su domicilio.

Mariana está solicitando un préstamo por US $250 para comprar una mesa más grande y ollas más grandes para poder ampliar su negocio, ofreciendo pagar el préstamo en 3 meses. Ella y su familia te agradecen el apoyo que les brindas para continuar creciendo con su negocio.

loans.use: To purchase a larger table and larger pots to expand her business

loans.name: Aicha

texts.en: S. Aicha is a fruit and vegetable seller in Treichville, in the south of Abidjan. She largely sells pepper at this time of the year corresponding to the production season of this product. She supplies various restaurants and some pepper paste artisan producers. S. Aicha is 31 years old and has 2 children. The elder is in primary school. She will use the loan to purchase batches of pepper from the production field.

loans.use: Sylla Aicha will use the loan to purchase goods from the production field

loans.name: Ina

texts.en:
G. INA lives in Treichville, in the south of Abidjan. She is 26 years old and sells various vegetables in the Treichville market. Guido is a single mother living with 2 children in a small house near the market. Her elder son will start primary school in October 2007.

Guido wants to expand her business. She currently sells cabbage and salad and plans to purchase bulk batches of onion for retail. G. has been running her business for six years. She got her first loan from AE&I in 2005 and has performed very well so far.

loans.use: Guindo Ina will use the loan to purchase goods and pay the school expenses for her elder daughter

loans.name: Astou

texts.en:
This is a group loan to be shared by the ten women of the Tocossone group, led by Ms. Astou N.. In their loan application, the group introduced their business as follows:

“The recent years of drought have impoverished our rural area, and many of the women's traditional income-supplementing activities are no longer viable. The consequences of desertification affect people at every level, but women are the most vulnerable. This is why the processing and marketing of local foods is so crucial for food security in rural areas, which is increasingly under threat. The members of the Tocossone group are highly motivated and have extensive experience in processing local food products. With the loan, the members of our group will reactivate local food sales by buying and selling products made from locally available produce in the surrounding village markets. Each member will specialize in producing and marketing her own niche product in order to increase the group's income.”

Original French business description:

«Avec les conséquences des années de sécheresse, le milieu rurale s’est beaucoup appauvrit et beaucoup d’activités jadis occupées par les femmes c’est petit à petit dévalorisées et du même coup a diminuer le pouvoir d’achat des femmes.

Les conséquences de la désertification n’épargnent aucune couche sociale. Les femmes sont les plus vulnérables de même que leur environnement agresser de partout. On comprend mieux pourquoi la valorisation des produits locaux et la transformation des céréales locales sont des enjeux pour la sécurité alimentaire dans le milieu rural. les paysans peinent à relever le défi de la sécurité alimentaire. Les membres du groupement TOCOSSONE sont très dynamiques et ont une très grande expérience sur la transformation des produits locaux. Avec le prêt les femmes membres de la cellule de l’éco village vont redynamiser le petit commerce avec l’achat et la revente des produits liés aux ressources naturelles dans les loumas environnants. Pour le volet transformation des produits locaux ; les femmes membres spécialisées s’en chargeront dans leur unité de transformation et les produits revendus pour accroître les revenus des membres. »

Background:

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group. Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines. Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities. Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members. However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income. This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities. The SEM Fund works to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance. Visit our website at www.sem-fund.org to learn more!

loans.use: To purchase pineapples, mangoes, hibiscus flowers, baobab fruit and tamarind, to manufacture juices and preserves

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance Fund (SEM) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nicolás

texts.es:
Nicolás is single and a mason. On the side, he also works various other gardening jobs, but principal skills are in masonry. He started this work in order to have other sources of income but grew to develop his work to engage in buying and selling iron and other metals. For 6 years, he worked with a business partner until Nicolás became independent. He now works for himself and wishes to advance in his career.

Nicolás is seeking a loan of $375 to buy raw materials for his work and a scale to weigh the iron and metals that he buys and sells. He will pay the loan back in 6 months. He thanks you for the support that allows him to continue and develop his business.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

Nicolás es un hombre trabajador y esta soltero, él es albañil y también se dedica a varios trabajos de jardinería, pero su mayor destreza es la de albañil, el empezó con el ofició por la necesidad de tener recursos económicos que le permitan vivir y poco a poco poder ir creciendo, quiere además de su trabajo se dedica a vender y comprar fierro y metales, fue hace 6 años que empezó a trabajar con un compañero, hasta que se independizó y ahora trabaja por su cuenta, él desea salir adelante con su trabajo.

Nicolás esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 375 para comprar materia prima para su trabajo y una báscula para pesar el fierro y metales que compra y vende, ofreciendo pagar el préstamo en 6 meses. Él te agradece mucho el apoyo que le das para poder continuar con su negocio y trabajo y poder crecer con su esfuerzo.

loans.use: to buy raw materials and a weighing scale

loans.name: Nohemi Guadalupe

texts.es:
Nohemi is married and has two children. Her husband is now employed, but Nohemi started her business because her husband had lost his job and they didn't have enough income to be able to live or to support their children. She decided to sell hamburgers at night and grew her business little by little. Now her business is the principal source of income for her family, and she has many customers. She wishes to keep growing her business.

Nohemi is requesting a loan of $750 to buy a larger grill, satisfy her demand, and put a roof on part of her business, because when it rains, she can't provide good service. With this loan, she will improve her location, and her customers will be more comfortable. She is offering to repay the loan in six months. Nohemi and her family thank you very much for the support that you offer them to grow their business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer.

Nohemi esta casada y tiene 2 hijos, su esposo trabaja como empleado en una empresa, ella empezó con su negocio por que su esposo se encontraba desempleado y no tenían ingresos para poder vivir ni mantener a sus niños, por ello ella se decidió a vender hamburguesas por las noches y poco a poco fue creciendo con su negocio y ahora su negocio es su principal fuente de ingresos, que se encuentra en su casa y ya cuenta con mucha clientela y desea continuar y seguir creciendo con su negocio.

Noemí esta solicitando un préstamo por US $ 750 para comprar una parrilla más grande y poder cubrir su demanda además techar una parte de su negocio por que la lluvia no le permite dar un buen servicio y con esto mejorará su local y sus clientes estarán más cómodos, ofreciendo pagar el préstamo en 6 meses. Ella y su familia te agradecen mucho el apoyo que le brindas para crecer con su negocio.

loans.use: To purchase a grill and to put a roof on part of her business

loans.name: Eduardo Alonzo

texts.es:
Eduardo is married and works as a taxi driver. His wife is a homemaker who takes care of their two children. He began working as a taxi driver due to the difficulty he had finding a job because of high rates of unemployment and because of his age, which complicated the situation even more. As a result, he decided to become self-employed so he could support his family.

6 years ago, he began driving a taxi by renting a car and now, he already has his own vehicle. The car is in use 24 hours a day because at night, he also rents it to a man that uses it for special jobs and long trips.

Eduardo is asking for a loan of $375 for the maintenance of his car. He is offering to pay back the loan within 5 months.

He is very grateful for your support so he can continue working and growing his business.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

Eduardo esta casado y trabaja como taxista, su esposa se dedica al hogar, al cuidado de sus dos hijos, él empezó con esta actividad debido a que existía mucho desempleo y por su edad se complicaba más la situación, por ello decidió trabajar como taxi y por su cuenta y así poder mantener a su familia. Hace 6 años empezó rentando un carro y ahora ya tiene su propio vehículo y lo trabaja las 24 horas, ya que el turno de noches el lo renta a un señor para que lo trabaje y a veces le salen trabajos especiales o viajes largos.

Eduardo esta solicitando un préstamo por la cantidad de US $ 375 para mantenimiento de su carro y ofrece pagar el pagar el préstamo en 5 meses. Él te agradece mucho el apoyo que le das para poder continuar con su trabajo y poder crecer con el mismo.

loans.use: Maintenance of taxi.

loans.name: Sayaad Nasirdin Shah

texts.en: Sayaad Nasirdin Shah lives in district 5 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He lives with his own family. He has two sons, and they are married. He is a old man. He has a retail shop. He has a lot of experience doing his job. He wants to support his family better, so he requested a loan to buy extra materials like rice, baskets, sweets, etc., to make a good income and help his family. He will be very happy with this loan.

loans.use: To buy extra materials like rice, baskets, sweets, etc.

loans.name: Jean Paul

texts.en: Jean Paul A., lives in Treichville (southern Abidjan), near the city hall. Born in 1976, he has more than ten years of work experience in selling bananas and other fruits in Treichville market. A. is single. He joined our micro-credit program in 2005 when he received a loan to purchase various fruits (orange, mangoes, etc.). He has performed very well since then.

loans.use: To purchase goods

loans.name: Miezan Elisabeth

texts.en:
Mrs. Miessan Elizabeth A. is a fresh vegetables seller in Treichville market in the southern area of the city of Abidjan. She was born in 1955. She has 23 years of experience and is very happy to have a career at the market. Her goal now is to develop her activities, so she joined AE&I a few months ago after she heard about it from her eldest son.

Miessan Elizabeth is the mother of 2 boys, who are both studying at the state university of Cocody in Cote d'Ivoire.

loans.use: To purchase goods

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en: Leonida, 32, a married mother of three sons, has a grocery store. To start her business a year ago, she took out a loan from FSMA which she repaid successfully. Now, she is requesting a loan to expand her inventory so that she can face the growing demand from her clientele. She plans to purchase wholesale goods like flour, sugar, butter, spaghetti, rice, peas, salt and other items that people in the community need. Given this loan, she’ll be able to better satisfy her customers’ needs and at the same time help her husband support their family.

loans.use: To purchase goods like flour, sugar, butter, and spaghetti to satisfy demand

loans.name: Eylin López

texts.en: Eylin is 23 years old, married, and the mother of a beautiful boy. Her son is 3 years old and is going into kindergarten. Her husband has a barber shop, and she sells clothes. Both businesses are run in their house. Eylin and her husband started their business more than two years ago. Eylin has already taken out a loan from our organization, and she used it wisely and repaid it in the time agreed upon. Her husband’s barber shop was made of wood, but she remodeled it with the loan and grew the business. The entrepreneur is now asking for a loan to expand her clothes store. She wants to purchase large amounts of clothes so as to better satisfy her customers’ needs. She’ll also help her husband hire two more hairdressers in the barber shop so they can attend to the customers more quickly.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and hire two hairdressers to expand her business

loans.name: Fiorentina Laurencia

texts.en: Fiorentina is 37 years old, married, and the mother of six children. Her husband is a mechanic and is working in a motor repair company. The couple wants to start an auto repair shop where they can sell motor parts and other accessories like motor oil, tires, spark plugs, and so forth. Given this loan, Fiorentina and her husband will be independent and able to better provide for their large family and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase motor oil, spark plugs, tires and other products to start an auto repair shop

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en: Catalina, 26, is happily married and the mother of four children (three boys and a girl).  Except the youngest, who is just two years old, they go to the public school of the township. Her husband is working in a construction company in the same township. Catalina has a grocery store and a small beauty salon in her house. She started the business about two years ago. She sells basic foodstuff like potatoes, bananas, carrots, onions, and other groceries that people can’t easily get in the area. At night, she sells soups and drinks. She also offers hairdos and hair straightening. The entrepreneur is asking for a loan to expand her inventory in order to better satisfy the customers' needs. This way, she’ll be able to help her husband financially support the family.

loans.use: To purchase goods like potatoes, carrots and other groceries to diversify her inventory

loans.name: Petrona

texts.en: Petrona is 26 years old, single, and living with her parents. Her five brothers and sisters live in Santo Domingo, because they go to the university there. Her parents are farmers. Petrona sells clothes and shoes in her parents’ house. She started that business one year ago after being obliged to drop out of school for financial reasons. Her parents couldn’t provide the transport for her, since she had to spend more than $40 a week to go to school in the city. Currently she is back in school, since she earns sufficient money from her business. The entrepreneur needs a loan to purchase more clothes and shoes, because she has these in short supply. She is working hard to grow her business so as to improve living conditions for herself and her family.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of clothes and shoes for her business, since these are in short supply

loans.name: Idalicia

texts.en: Idalicia is a single woman of 55 years who is living with her two nephews. Her sons (33 and 24 years old) go to the university in Santo Domingo, the capital. She sells secondhand clothes that she buys wholesale every two weeks. The entrepreneur has already taken out one loan, which she repaid successfully. Currently, Idalicia is requesting another loan in order to rent a small shop where she can sell the clothes. Since she started the business, she has been selling her products in the streets. She thinks that having her own shop would be handy for her and her clientele.

loans.use: To rent a small shop to sell clothes and buy a large quantity of inventory

loans.name: Fior Dalisa

texts.en: Fior, 22 years old, is married with two daughters. The eldest is finishing kindergarten and will enter primary school next year. The other was born just four months ago. Fior’s husband is an independent businessman and sells different kinds of goods. The loan requested is to buy goods like flour, sugar, rice, wheat, peas and vegetable oil. These are some of the most-bought products in her community, and there are just two other "colmados" (grocery stores) in a range of 12 km. So, her business is very useful to the community, since people in that community can get the basic foodstuffs there without walking very long distances.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, wheat and other basic foodstuffs, which are in short supply

loans.name: Margarita Encarnació

texts.en: Margarita, 20, is one of the few young people in her community to cultivate the entrepreneurial spirit. She is also very responsible. She got married last year to another young man of 25. Four years ago, she started her business selling clothes, hair products and skin care products. Her store is well known by people of the township and she has an established clientele. The loan requested is to buy hair gel, since this has been in short supply. Margarita uses a part of her income to help her mother, who sometimes helps her attend to the business.

loans.use: To purchase more hair gel for her business

loans.name: Juana

texts.en: Juana, 57, is the mother of seven children (five boys and two girls). Her husband died a year ago, and since then life has changed drastically for her family. As she is undereducated, she couldn’t get a better-paying job that could help her tend to her children's needs. So, she was obliged to earn a living selling fuel and oil for motorcycles. Juana needs a loan to purchase a large amount of gas and oil. This way, she’ll not have to go to the capital every weekend to buy small quantities of these products. She’ll also be better able to handle her housing concerns.

loans.use: To purchase fuel and motor oil for her small business, since these products are running out

loans.name: Ni Putu

texts.id:
After marrying I Komang Darmawan 5 years ago, Ni Putu A. of Tukadaya village has to work hard to supplement her husband's income. Her husband works as a contract farmer with low and uncertain income. With strong motivation, Ni Putu A. started a small pig farm to support herself and her husband. Ni Putu A. started her business with 2 pigs, from which she gained $15 profit per month. Which helps a lot to pay her daily expense of about $1.50. With Dinari loan of $175, Ni Putu A. plans to buy 3 additional grower pigs, while the rest is used to renovate her pig pens.
