She hopes that with additional capital, her business can grow faster, thus increase her family's quality of life. A. is also worried about having to start paying tuition for her 4 year old daughter, Ni Luh Adelia who will start kindergarten next year.

Translated by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva volunteer

Sejak menikah dengan I Komang Darmawan 5 tahun yang lalu , Ni Putu A. wanita asli kelahiran desa Tukadaya ini harus bekerja keras untuk dapat membantu pendapatan suami yang punya penghasilan rendah sebagai petani penggarap tanah milik orang lain. Dengan bermodalkan tekad dan ketekunan yang dimiliki Ni Putu A. memulai usaha kecil yang bisa mendukung penghasilan suaminya itu. Beternak babi itulah usaha yang dijalankannya sampai saat ini. Ni Putu A. mulai usahanya dengan memelihara 2 ekor ternak babi dan dari dua ekor babi itu Ni Putu A. memperoleh ke untungan sebesar Rp 150.000,- / bulan , hasil yang menurutnya sangat berarti untuk memenuhi biaya kebutuhan sehari-hari yang mencapai Rp 15.000,- Hal ini juga yang mendorongnya untuk mengembangkan usaha itu. Dengan modal pinjaman dari Dinari Rp 1.500.000,- Ni Putu A. bermaksud membeli 3 ekor bibit babi lagi sedangkan sisa uangnya di pergunakan untuk membeli bahan atap untuk kandangnya . Besar harapan Ni PutuA. dengan tambahan modal ini usahanya akan lebih maju sehingga hasilnya bisa mendongkrak perekonomian keluarganya , dan A. juga harus memulai memikirkan Putrinya Ni Luh Adelia yang telah berumur 4 tahun saat ini karena tahun depan sudah membutuhkan biaya untuk mulai bersekolah di Taman Kanak-kanak.

loans.use: Purchase piglets

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Luh

texts.id:
Curretnly Ni Luyuh T. farms 3 pigs. The loan from DINARI is going to be used to purchase pig feeds supply for several months. Her three breeding pigs can give birth to about 20 piglets every six months. Ni luh T. diligently feeds her 3 pigs with help from her husband. She sells her piglets in a staggered manner as each piglets does not mature at the same rate. Piglets that she deems fat and mature enough are sold first. Her sales are about $400 in each 6 months. Her feeds cost can reach about $220 so she gets about $180 net profit per 6 months. She uses that earnings to support her husband and pay tuition for her children

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Saat ini Ni luh T. memelihara 3 ekor induk babi. Dana pinjaman dari DINARI dipergunakan untuk membeli pakan babi untuk beberapa bulan kedepan. Dari ketiga induk babinya melahirkan kurang lebih 20 ekor bibit setiap enam bulannya .Untuk itulah Ni luh T. selalu rajin memberi makan ketiga ekor babinya dengan di bantu oleh suaminya. Jangka waktu pemeliharaan ke 20 ekor bibit babi hanya 3 bulan. Penjualan dilakukan bertahap karena pertumbuhan bibit tidak merata. Bibit yang sudah cukup gemuk dan bagus, dijual terlebih dahulu dan yang lain berikutnya. Total penjualan dalam waktu 6 bulan mencapai Rp. 4.000.000,- biaya pakan mencapai Rp. 2.200.000,- keuntungan bersih Rp. 1.800.000,- dari hasil tersebut digunakan untuk membantu pendapatan suaminya dan membiayai sekolah anak- anaknya.

loans.use: Purchase piglets

loans.name: Ni Kadek

texts.id:
In order to help her family's income, Ni Kadek W. farms a pig. Every morning and evening, she prepares feeds for her pig. Each breeding pig can give birth to 8 piglets which she farms for 3 months. After those piglets are quite mature, they are sold to grower farms. It is Balinese custom to farm pigs for consumer and religious ceremonies. Each pigs can be sold for about $35 to $40. Her total revenue can reach $300, with $70 net profit. Most of her cost is for feeds. From this earnings, she still could not support her family of 5. Ni Kadek W. needs additional $175 capital with which she plans to buy 2 more breeding pigs, so she can increase her earnings and better help her husband to support her family.

Translated by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Untuk membantu menopang perekonomian keluarganya Ni Kadek W. memelihara 1 induk babi .Setiap pagi dan sore menyiapkan pakan untuk babinya. Satu induk dapat melahirkan 8 ekor bibit babi dan dipelihara selama 3 bulan. Setelah dirasa cukup besar kemudian anak babi dijual. Kebiasaan yang ada di Bali adalah keperluan daging babi untuk konsumsi dan keperluan untuk upacara keagamaan. Harga per ekornya mencapai Rp. 350.000.- sampai dengan Rp. 400.000,- Total penjualan seluruhnya dapat mencapai Rp. 3.000.000,-Keuntungan bersih mencapai Rp. 700.000,- setelah dikurangi semua pengeluaran untuk pakan. Dari pendapatan ini belum bisa menopang kehidupan keluarganya yang berjumlah 5 orang. Ni Kadek W. membutuhkan tambahan modal usaha Rp. 1.400.000.- Harapan kedepannya akan membeli 2 ekor induk lagi sehingga keuntungan akan lebih banyak lagi, sehingga dapat membantu pendapatan suami untuk mencukupi kebutuhan keluarganya.

loans.use: Purchase pig feed

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Nguyen Thi V., 39 years old, has joined TYM Fund since 2000. She is an active woman. Her husband Le V. Thu, an officer of commune Tien Duoc, and she discussed and decided to get a loan from TYM Fund to open a grocery store right at home to provide the needs of her villagers. The income generated from the store is 180 USD per month. This amount and her husband’s salary is enough for their daily expenses and tuition and fees for their 3 children. Two of her children are about to finish their middle and high school, while their oldest child is in college in Hanoi. V. and Thu are now planning to upgrade the store and buy more groceries to meet the demands for the coming Tet holidays. This time she would like to borrow 1200USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Vân, 39 tuổi tham gia Quỹ Tình thương từ năm 2000. Bản thân là một người phụ nữ năng động chị đã cùng với chồng là anh Lê Văn Thu, cán bộ xã Tiên Dược, bàn bạc vay vốn để kinh doanh mặt hàng tạp hoá ngay tại nhà để phục vụ nhu cầu tiêu dùng của đông đảo bà con trong thôn. Tổng thu nhập từ cửa hàng trong 1 tháng là 180USD, cộng thêm tiền lương của chồng giúp gia đình đủ điều kiện kinh tế để trang trải cho những chi phí thường ngày và cho các con ăn học đầy đủ. 3 con chị hiện nay đều đang học đến những năm cuối cấp, riêng cháu đầu đang học cao đẳng ngoài Hà Nội. Hiện tại gia đình chị có kế hoạch sửa chữa nâng cấp cửa hàng và nhập thêm nhiều mặt hàng để phục vụ cho dịp tết Nguyên đán sắp tới, nếu được vay thêm 1200 USD.

loans.use: buy groceries, etc drinks, candy ...

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Jero Ketut

texts.id:
Jero Ketut M. owns a pig farm with 3 grower pigs to be slaughtered. She diligently feeds her pigs twice a day. This cost her about $25 for 3 months. After 3 months, she sells mature pigs for $40 each,with total sales of $120. She earns about $70 in profit for 3 months. However, each month Jero Ketut needs to spend $60 for her family living expenses. Currently Jero Ketut needs additional capital of $140. Her plan is to add more farmed pigs, so she can increase her earnings to support her family and pay her children's school tuition.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Jero Ketut M. mengembangkan usaha beternak babi dengan memelihara 3 ekor bibit babi untuk penggemukan.Dengan tekun setiap hari memberi makan sebanyak 2 kali. Biaya pakan selama 3 bulan mencapai Rp.250.000,- Setelah 3 bulan dijual dengan harga setiap ekornya mencapai Rp. 400.000,- total seluruh penjualan Rp.1.200.000, Jadi keuntungan bersih selama 3 bulan mencapai Rp.700.000,- padahal setiap bulannya Jero Ketut M. harus mengeluarkan biaya untuk kebutuhan hidupnya Rp 600.000. Saat ini Jero Ketut M. membutuhkan tambahan modal usaha Rp 1.400.000 Rencananya kedepan ingin lebih banyak lagi memelihara babi pengemukan sehingga keuntungan juga akan semakin meningkat untuk menunjang biaya hidup dan juga biaya sekolah anaknya.

loans.use: Purchase piglets

loans.name: Truong Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Truong Thi G., 52 years old, has been a member of TYM Fund for 11 year. Her husband got a disease and died in 1998, making her life even more difficult. Her four children and she put all of their efforts to earn money for the living. At the beginning she applied for a 200 USD loan to raise pigs. After substracting all the costs, her first pigs bring her 100 USD profit. She continues to apply for loans to expand her business. When all of her children have grown up, she applies for the highest loan to open a new store which provides building materials like gravel, sand, etc. Her total income from both the pigs and the store in Trung Gia commune, Soc Son district is around 370 – 430 USD. Her two oldest children just get married, so the family expenses increase. She would like to apply for a 1200 USD loan to expand her business model to increase her income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trương Thị Gái, 52 tuổi, đã tham gia Quỹ Tình thương được 11 năm. Chồng chị mắc bệnh qua đời năm 1998 khiến cho hoàn cảnh kinh tế gia đình rất khó khăn. Chị cùng bốn người con đều phải nỗ lực tham gia vào việc phát triển kinh tế gia đình. Lúc đầu chị xin vay mức vốn 200 USD về chăn nuôi lợn. Lứa lợn đầu tiên sau khi trừ chi phí mang lại cho chị khoảng 100 USD. Trong các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị tiếp tục vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. Khi các con đã trưởng thành chị xin vay mức vốn tối đa đầu tư thêm vào việc kinh doanh cát sỏi vật liệu xây dựng. Mức doanh thu hàng tháng từ đàn lợn và cửa hàng vật liệu xây dựng tại xã Trung Giã, huyện Sóc Sơn khoảng từ 370 đến 430 USD đủ để trang trải cho cuộc sống hàng ngày của 5 mẹ con. Hai con lớn của chị Gái vừa lập gia đình riêng, mức chi phí của cả gia đình nâng cao nên chị đang cần vay thêm 1200 USD để mở rộng mô hình kinh doanh nhằm nâng cao thu nhập.

loans.use: buy some pigs and building materials like gravel, sand ...

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: I am Rukhsana G. and the mother of an only daughter, who is too young to go to school. I am uneducated but I hope that the same fate does not befall my daughter. I stitch clothes on order from my neighborhood whereas my husband sells cows in a nearby livestock market. He is able to earn a profit of $ 30 to $35 on every cow he sells but he is able to buy and sell only three cows a month. Now my husband wants to buy another animal (cow) to increase his income. I will also pool in my savings and require a loan of USD 250 for my husband.

loans.use: Buy a cow

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Hafeezan

texts.en: I am Hafeezan B. and I live in Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. My husband is a daily wage laborer while my daughter and I stitch clothes on order from my neighborhood. My eldest son works for a local newspaper printing press whereas the other one makes embroidered clothes on a four-legged embroidery frame. I want my children to have a decent living, which is possible with a good income. I have planned to create a joint-venture between my stitching business and my son’s embroidery business. The outfits that we will prepare we will sell  to various expensive boutiques in our city. This venture can generate decent profits to us. We need USD250 to buy the required stuff.

loans.use: EXPAND CLOTHING BUSINESS

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Munawar

texts.en: I have been stitching clothes for the past twenty years so I have a lot of experience. My husband is a company driver at a local company in Karachi      ( the biggest city in Pakistan ) for a pay of $65 a month. At times he is not able to send us a single penny for he has to make his own living as well in that expensive city. I wish to educate my child  who is not yet of school-going age. Before that time comes, I need to have a steady source of income. I therefore would like to buy a new stitching machine for myself that costs $175 so I can generate more income.

loans.use: buy a stitching machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en: I am Kalsoom A. and the mother of four children. I am a housewife and cannot go out and work as it is not considered acceptable in the community where I live. My husband sells vegetables on his cart in a nearby vegetable market. Last year I took a loan for his business, which yielded us an extra profit of $50 a month. We could not afford to send our children to school due to our poor financial condition. We need more money to make ends meet and so I request a loan of USD325 , to expand our vegetable business.

loans.use: EXPAND VEGETABLE BUSINESS

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en: I am Kalsoom B. and I was born and brought up in Mian Chunnu ( a small town in Pakistan) and then moved to Multan (a mid-sized city in Pakistan) after I got married. I am the mother of five children all of whom attend school. I make and sell embroidered clothes to the nearby  markets; I have also hired afew women to help me in this business. The business yields approximately $65 a month in profit. My husband works in WAPDA (a government institution that provides electricity) as a lineman for nominal wages. My embroidered clothes are unique in design and the latest in fashion but due to a lack of resources, I cannot produce a large quantity. I need a loan of USD250 to produce more and thereby profit more. I will make savings with these extra profits and plan to buy a piece of land to construct a house on.

loans.use: Expand embroidery business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Faiz

texts.en: I am Faiz B., a mother of six children. Two of my daughters are married whereas the youngest one supports me in my embroidery and stitching business. The eldest son operates a fruit cart, which I bought him from a loan I have previously taken, and the son after  him drives a rented rickshaw. I was unable to educate them because of our poor financial condition, but now we are doing better and therefore I have enrolled my youngest in school. My son is quite an expert in driving by now and he wishes to operate his own rickshaw, which will maximize his profits, as he will no more have to pay the rent. I need a loan of USD425  for my son to purchase  a rickshaw on installments.

loans.use: Buy rickshaw for my son

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Balqees

texts.en: My name is Balqees A. and I am a widow. I have only one daughter and currently she is doing a Master's Degree in English. After my husband's death I started making and selling embroidered clothes, I go door-to-door and sell my clothes. I work in the evening as a part-time front desk officer in a small academy for $35 only. I work very hard day and night to meet the daily expenses and help my daughter complete her education. I wish to expand my business and make a small boutique in my house, because I am getting older and I will not be able to sell door to door in the years to come. It will also help to generate better profits that I will save for my daughter’s marriage.I need a loan of USD175.

loans.use: Make a boutique

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: I Nyoman

texts.id:
As a Subak (traditional Balinese agricultural system) manager I Nyoman P. tries to provide agricultural supplies to his community. He sells various kinds of fertilizer, such as ponska,urea, and TSP. With about $600 capital, I Nyoman P. supply to provide fertilizer needs for 35 farmers with 25 Ha land area. This fertilizer is sold to the farmers to fulfill their needs. Currently, I Nyoman P. has not been able to meet the demand of all farmers because of capital limitation. In 1 month, I Nyoman P. can earn about $60 profit from his fertilizer sales. I Nyoman P. wants to increase his inventory up to 10 tonnes. To do so he needs additional $600 capital. HOpefully with the additional capital and inventory, he can double his business profit.

Translated form Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

I Nyoman P. sebagai pengurus subak mencoba menyediakan sarana produksi pertanian.Berbagai jenis pupuk untuk petani disediakannya seperti : Pupuk Ponska, Urea ,TSP .Dengan modal usaha Rp. 6 .000.0000,-, I Nyoman P. berusaha menyediakan kebutuhan pupuk untuk 35 orang petani dengan lahan seluas 25 Ha. Pupuk ini dijualnya kepada para petani sesuai dengan kebutuhannya masing-asing.Saat ini I Nyoman P. belum mampu melayani semua kebutuhan petani karena keterbatasan modal . Dalam 1 bulan I Nyoman P. bisa mendapat keuntungan Rp. 600.000,-.dari penjualan pupuknya. I Nyoman P. bermaksud menambah pupuk sampai 10 ton lagi ia masih perlu modal sekitar Rp. 6.000.000,-.Dengan tambahan modal ini ia akan mampu mendapat untung dua kali lipatnya.

loans.use: Fertilizer purchase

loans.name: Manzoor

texts.en: I am the mother of four children, two daughters and two sons, all of whom study. I feel it is important to educate them in order to make them better human beings who can earn a good living for themselves. To support my husband ( who works as a daily wage laborer), I started  stitching clothes for my neighborhood clients since I got married .As my children are growing, so are their needs and we feel the need of extra income. Therefore, I have decided to expand my business, and offer peco and over-lock facilities to my clients in addition to stitching. I need a loan of USD 250 to buy a new stitching machine that can make peco and over-lock as well.

loans.use: Buy a latest stitching machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: I was born and brought up in Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. I am the mother of four children, all of whom I have managed to enroll in  school. My husband and I both stitch sacks used to store various types of grains and rice and sell them in the nearby grain market. Last year we took a loan from ASASAH, a microfinance institution, and invested in our sack business. We were able to repay the installments on time and buy a few items such as a fridge and a washing machine for ourselves. Now we need to expand our business further and require USD325 as a loan.

loans.use: Expand business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Zohran

texts.en: I am Zorhan B. and the mother of five. I am a  cleaner and I work in three to four houses for a nominal income of $20 altogether. My husband is a tailor and operates a rented tailoring shop in a nearby market. My eldest son works as a furniture painter at a furniture shop and my eldest daughter is married. The rest of my children attend school. The clients of my husband are quite satisfied with his work and therefore the number of clients is increasing day by day. In order to respond promptly to his clients he needs to buy an additional sewing machine, hire a helper and buy threads etc. We require a loan of USD250.

loans.use: Buy stitching machine for my husband

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Farhat

texts.en: I am a widow, and I have four children. My children had to suspend their studies after their father died. Previously I took a loan for my eldest son to buy him a rickshaw on installments, whereas my other son started supplying saris (a local dress famous in India and Pakistan) to a sari dealer with the help of his friend. Our income gradually got better and I was able to support the marriage of one of my daughters. My youngest daughter and I press and pack the saris for my son. My son buys the fabric used in these saris from a local cloth market and gets them embroidered on order. There is a high demand for such saris; however, due to limited resources, we can only supply a small quantity. We need to expand our business and thus require US$325.

loans.use: Expand sari business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Firdos

texts.en:
I am Firdos B. and I have four children. I stitch clothes to order for my neighborhood clientele. My husband operates a vegetable cart with the help of our eldest son. Our monthly income is approximately US$ 120.

Last year I took a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution, and invested the money in my husband’s vegetable business. The profits got better and we were able to raise our meager standard of living. We also managed to buy a donkey for our cart. My husband plans to expand his business further and open a vegetable shop. He needs a loan of US$ 325 to add to our savings to use for this purpose.

loans.use: Expand my husband's vegetable business

loans.name: Shabana

texts.en:
I am Shabana T. from Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. I am the mother of three children. My eldest son is studying in grade one, whereas my other children are too young to go to school. My husband and I manufacture vermicelli on order from various shops. We buy the ingredients from a nearby factory at reasonable prices.

On the Eid ( a religious festival) the demand for vermicelli increases as it is used in the making of different types of deserts. If we are able to produce more, we will be able to get higher returns. I need a loan of US$ 250 to invest in our business.

loans.use: Expand vermicelli-manufacturing business

loans.name: Taj

texts.en:
I am a widow and to earn a living, I spin strands of nylon that are used in making a char pai (a bedstead that is four-legged and mostly used in our villages). My eldest son has a stitching machine with which he does peco and overlock stitching for neighborhood clients. My other two sons are a laborer and an apprentice at a woodworking shop respectively.

Together we earn $200 a month with which it is very hard to feed and clothe the seven children in our family.

My son has acquired a suitable level of expertise as an apprentice and now he wish to operate his own shop. He will use his savings but also requires a loan of US$ 250 to buy a lathe (a machine for use in working wood, metal, etc.; it holds the material firmly and rotates it about a horizontal axis against a tool that shapes it.)

loans.use: Buy a lathe for her son to use to open a business

loans.name: Gulam Ayesha

texts.en: I live in Multan, a mid-sized city in Pakistan. I am the mother of five children. My husband and I make small carpets on hand looms. This business can yield very handsome profits to us if we can expand the variety, but for that we require a loan of US$ 250. With this loan, we will be able to buy the raw materials that are required in weaving carpets in bulk. We sell these carpets in nearby cities to small expensive stores.

loans.use: Expand carpet weaving business

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is 34 years old, married and has four children. Two of her children are in secondary while two are in primary school.

From her one-room home, she makes envelopes. She finds colorful blue and pink paper that has been recycled from government forms. Very neatly, she folds the paper together. With a jar of paste and a wood stick, she seals the edges, leaving a pocket open on one end. She makes hundreds of these envelopes at a time.

There is a photo shop in downtown Kampala which pays her for the envelopes. The photo shop will use the envelopes to place one picture in each envelope.

She has been making envelopes for three years now. She is now also a member of a women’s lending group, which is located in the Rabaga District of Kampala, Uganda. After weeks of attending meetings and understanding the concept of receiving a loan, she is ready for her first loan.

She hopes to buy larger supplies, paper and paste, and perhaps hire someone to help her make the envelopes. Since she is new to the process, she is a little reserved, perhaps a little nervous about this “first step”. However, she is excited for the opportunity this loan can give her and her family.

loans.use: To buy more paper and paste for her business

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Mrs. Sam S. L., age 23, runs a small lottery business in her community near Siem Reap, earning about $2.50 per day. She would like to borrow $600 to purchase a motorbike so that her husband can operate a moto-taxi business to earn $2 per day. They have no children, but plan to save money for their children's education in the future. Her husband, also age 23, is pictured here next to the motorbike they would like to buy.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to operate a business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. is a 38 year old, single woman. She has four children of her own and takes care of two others from her immediate family.

She has a small store that is reachable by a path in the Rubaga District of Kampala. Rubaga is made up of a maze of paths so one could easily get lost there. Her store is only about 12 feet wide and four to five feet deep.

When you arrive at her store, there is a bench outside to rest and visit. A small plank of wood leans precariously and on it are a few small tomatoes and onions. You don’t really “enter” the store, but instead, you sort of step up and face it. In front of the store are wall-to-wall bars of welded rebar with a rebar door you can duck under. This is constructed so that when she leaves, she can “lock up”. Very neatly arranged on the back wall are domestic items such as toothpaste, sodas, sugar, muffins in bags, etc. There is a small cooler for soft drinks and soap comes in long bars which she cuts to the requested size.

Rose has operated at this location for seven years and she has been a client of the Rubaga Women’s Lending Group for one and half years. She carries herself with respect and authority. You can tell she is an important member of her community. With her loan,she hopes to hire someone to operate this shop and to open another shop of the same nature.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To hire someone for her store and open another store

loans.name: Bena

texts.en:
Bena K. is a 35 year-old, married woman. She has five children, three of whom are in secondary school, one in primary and one in “baby class”.

Bena has a retail shop on one of the only “roads” at the edge of the Rubaga District. She has run the business for the past five years and has been a part of the Rubaga Women’s Lending Group for three years. Her store is large for Rubaga standards - around 10’x 20’ - and is well-stocked. Often, small “distributors” bring items to stock the stores. As with most retail stores, items sold are similar. However, each store still has a character of its own.

Bena is hard-working and has an enthusiastic, entrepreneur’s spirit. Her husband appears to be very supportive, although he sometimes has to travel to Tanzania to work and is away for months at a time. Bena’s dream is to one day own the building she now rents. Her loan will be used to better stock her store, so that it may become one of the best in Rubaga.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To stock her store with an increase in staples: rice, sugar.

loans.name: Lumateh Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian was the second wife of Gideon N. who, because of a family misunderstanding, separated from her.  She is a mother of four children, three who are of schooling age.  Her separation from her husband has been a challenge to her as she now has the responsibility of taking care of her four children with very little support from their father.

With a loan of $100, she plans to invest in her tailoring business through which she plans to sew and sell dresses.  The profit will be used to pay school fees for her children and provide other basic needs for her children.

She plans to repay the loan in 15 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of cloth, sewing thread and pay workshop rent

loans.name: Robina

texts.en:
Robina N. is 36 years old, widowed and has three children. She also takes care of two of her brother's children. Her husband passed away when her first born was only seven. She runs a small hair salon that is located via a path, deep in the center of the Rubaga District of Kampala.

Robina has owned the business at this location for the past seven years. She has attained two loans which she has had no problems paying off. She plans to use the next loan to buy cosmetics, shampoo, hair dye and braids. It is not unusual to see women with beautifully braided hair in Rubaga.

Robina is a very confident woman. She talks about her finances openly and knows what she needs to do to improve her and her children's lives. Some interesting facts about her finances:

- On a good day she may gross $5.00 US.

- Her rent is $30.00 per month.

- She currently has no place of her own, so she often sleeps at the salon.

- Her children stay with a friend, though she sees them everyday.

- She is trying to grow her business so that she can afford rent and have her children back under one roof.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To increase her inventory of shampoo, cosmetics, hair dye and braids.

loans.name: Muminakhon

texts.ru:
Muminakhon H. is married, has a university degree and is the mother of two school-going children. Her husband is a teacher. She also works as a teacher and in her spare time she sells food and electronics at a market stall. Her husband runs the stall when she is teaching. She started selling food to supplement her income because teachers have very low salaries. After getting her first loan Muminakhon increased her sales, added clients and also added electronics to her inventory. Today her assets have doubled in value. She plans to use the new loan to open another market stall.

P.S. The photo is of her husband.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Хабибуллоева Муминахон замужем, мать двоих детей, образование высшее. Муж работает учителем, дети учатся в школе. Она занимается реализацией продуктов питания, также работает учительницей. Муж заменяет её во время её работы. Начала заниматься торговлей, поскольку зарплата учителей очень мизерная. После получения займа и целевого использования она величила товарооборот, приобрела много клиентов, добавила в свой ассортимент технику. Сейчас её активы возросли в два раза, и в будущем она планирует открыть ещё одну торговую точку. На фото её муж.

loans.use: To open another market stall

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann V., age 36, sells vegetables in an open-air market near Siem Reap, earning $7 per day in revenue. Her husband, age 40, works as a farmer to grow the vegetables and rice that she sells. They do not have children.

Vann would like to borrow $500 to repair their house after the monsoon season. In the future, she plans to diversify and expand the variety of crops they grow to reduce the risk of crop failure and provide a more secure income stream.

loans.use: To repair her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: I Ketut

texts.id:
As the head of the household, Pak Ketut D., is responsible for the livelihood of his 3 children. A husband from Kt Suarti, initially bred 3 pigs only with the intention of supplementing his farming work. However after seeing the great prospect of this effort, he enthusiastically expanded this effort. Within a year a breeder sow usually produces twice, bearing 7 to 10 piglets, each piglet on the average is worth Rp 150.000 (about USD20). For 2 hours each day, he set aside time for this, in the morning between 6-7 and afternoon after returning from farming. Currently, he already own 4 breeder sows of the local breed. This loan will be used to purchase another sow and a male breeder pig. From his earnings he can save more thus able to pay for his 2 sons’ education, already in primary and technical schools.

Translated from Indonesian to English by Pheng Tan, Kiva volunteer.

Pak Ketut D., sebagai kepala keluarga bertanggung jawab atas kelangsungan hidup ketiga orang anaknya. Suami dari Kt Suarti ini pada awalnya hanya memelihara 3 ekor babi saja dan menganggap usaha ini sebagai pekerjaan sambilan di samping sebagai petani penggarap tanah. Namun setelah melihat prospek usaha ini bagus dia berantusias untuk mengembangkannya. Dalam setahun 1 ekor induk babi bisa beranak 2 kali, dengan anak 7 - 10 ekor, sedangkan harga anak yang sudah siap di pisah rata-rata Rp 150.000 /ekor. 2 jam sehari dia meluangkan waktunya, pagi mulai pukul 06.00 Wita s/d jam 07.00 Wita dan sore setelah datang dari sawahnya. Saat ini Pak Ketut telah memiliki 4 ekor Induk babi Lokal. Pinjaman yang didapatkan digunakan untuk menambah 1 ekor induk dan 1 ekor pejantan. Harapannya dari keuntungan yang didapatkan dia bisa menabung lebih banyak dan mampu terus mampu membiayai dua orang Putranya yang kini sudah duduk di bangku sekolah SD dan STM.

loans.use: Purchase Breeding Pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. Chea P., age 34, sells grocery products to the people in her community, earning about $2 each day. Her husband, age 36, is a construction worker, earning about $5 per day. They have three children, two of whom are students; one is a construction worker.

Mrs. Chea P. would like to borrow $800 to purchase audio equipment to rent out for weddings and celebrations in her community. This will increase income for her family to help pay for her children’s education. She is pictured with her husband in front of her grocery products and the audio equipment they would like to purchase for their business.

loans.use: To purchase a stereo system, speakers, and an electrical generator to rent to the people in her area for their wedding celebrations

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Bih Esther

texts.en:
Esther will forever regret the fact that she dropped out of secondary school as a result of her father’s refusal to pay her school fees.  As a mother of five children, all below 15 years of age, she saw the need to start her own business so she would be able to help her husband take care of the children.

With a loan of $100, she plans to start a business manufacturing detergent and selling it.  Locally manufactured detergent is used by most people in the area because it is cheaper.  Her profit will be used to pay school fees for her children.

She plans to repay the loan in 15 months with the first installment on the day the loan is disbursed.

loans.use: Purchase of kernel oil, caustic soda and carbonate for detergent manufacturing

loans.name: Suy

texts.en:
Mrs. Suy R., age 48, is a widow and a housewife. She has four children, two of whom work in construction and together earn about $10 per day. One child works as a waiter, earning about $60 per month, and one child is married and no longer lives at home.

Suy would like to borrow $800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use as their transportation to work and to dig a well to serve as her family’s water source. They currently do not have running water.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her children to use as their transportation to work and to dig a well to serve as her family’s water source.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ning

texts.en:
Mrs. Ning S., age 33, is a widow and works as a recycler, buying, collecting, and re-selling recyclable items, earning about $8 per day in revenue. She has three children, one of whom sells souvenir products on the roadside to passing tourists near Angkor Wat, and two of whom are students.

Ning would like to borrow $700 to purchase more recyclable items for her business inventory. This will expand her income and help pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase more recyclable items for her business inventory

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 31 years old, widowed and cares for four children. Two of the children are her own and two are dependents.

She owns a beauty salon on a well-trafficked street on the edge of the Rubaga District of Kampala. One enters her salon through beads hung from the doorway. Broken chards of tile have been set in the floor. The walls are painted a robin’s egg blue. Whenever we meet with an entrepreneur, they always welcome us warmly, offer us a cleanly, wiped-down seat.

Today she sits and tells us this is her first loan. She has been in business at this location for 10 years. She wishes to obtain an additional loan in order to add a line of braids, hair weaving tools, along with increasing her line of shampoos and chemicals.

Fatuma dreams of one day owning small 10’ x 15’ storefront, where she would not have to pay rent. She is able to afford uniforms, hand-made from leftover cloth, for her children.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To buy weaving tools, shampoos and chemicals for hair dying

loans.name: Ke

texts.en: Mrs. Ke P., age 32, is a widow who runs a grocery business out of her home, earning about $3 per day. Her two children are too young to go to school or work. She would like to borrow $400 to expand her inventory of grocery products to grow her business and provide for her children’s education in the future.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Mathius

texts.en:
Mathius K. is a 40 year-old married man. He has five children of his own and cares for his brothers' five children.

For a living, Mathius sells charcoal. He has a 20’ x 20’ log rail, fenced corral covered by a roof of corrugated steel. His business is located in the heart of the Rubaga District of Kampala, reachable only by winding dirt paths. Currently, within the gated corral, he has a stack of 15 charcoal bags, each bag weighing approximately 110 kg. People enter the corral with one gallon plastic jugs and Mathius fills the single jug with charcoal. They will use this as fuel in their cooking pots which are placed outside their homes in Rubaga.

Mathius is gentle and well-known in Rubaga, for everyone cooks with charcoal. He has been selling charcoal for approximately 20 years and calls Rubaga his home. He does not dream of ever leaving Rubaga. However, he does dream of buying a plot of land with 10’ x 15’ dimensions to build a house.

With the loan, he wants to buy more charcoal. If he can buy in larger quantities, he will spend less time having to make trips to get the charcoal. He is increasing his sales to small hotels and restaurants in the area. These are one and two room dirt floor “hotels” and “restaurants” with outdoor cooking pots, tables and chairs.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To buy larger quantities of charcoal, thus reducing the number of trips he makes to get the charcoal.

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Mrs. Nov K. L., age 25, is a housewife who takes care of her two young children. She would like to borrow $500 to purchase a motorbike to attach to the cart in the picture so her husband can become a moto-taxi driver and earn $5 per day to support his family.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to operate a moto-taxi business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma N. is a young, 31 year-old mother of three children. She also cares for three other children. Three of her children are in secondary school and three are in “baby class”. She is bright, very kind and carries a natural and welcoming smile.

Fatuma is married and operates a retail store on the edge of Rubaga. She sells eggs, soda, soap, rice, sugar and items for personal hygiene. Since Fatuma's store is located on a busy street, she also has a wireless phone that people can pay to use. In addition, she resells the empty soda bottles.

Her business was located just a few hundred feet away, but the building was demolished two years ago. Her business suffered for a year after she moved, but now it is in decent condition.

She needs a loan to start to sell some items wholesale. Because she is on a busy street, she feels that sugar, salt, and rice could be sold to others who would then resell it. This could occur through a second loan.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To use her loan to start selling some items wholesale,i.e. sugar, salt, rice.

loans.name: Phav

texts.en: Mrs. Phav P., age 46, is a housewife near Siem Reap. She has three children, one of whom works in a restaurant and two of whom are students. Her husband, age 45, hulls rice for farmers to separate the rice from the husk, making about $1.50 per day. Mrs. Phav P. would like to borrow $750 to purchase a motorbike to transport the rice from the fields to the rice-huller and also provide her family with transportation. Her husband is pictured in the photo next to his rice-huller.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to transport rice crops and provide her family with transportation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Cheang

texts.en: Mrs.Cheang S., age 24, is a housewife who looks after her small child. Her husband works as a land broker, helping others buy and sell land, earning a commission of $4 per day. She would like to borrow $400 to purchase a motorbike to provide her family with transportation.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her family's transportation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sut

texts.en: Mrs. Sut S., age 29, runs a grocery store out of her home. Her husband works hard to raise and sell pigs, earning $2.50 per day. They have one small child that she looks after. She would like to borrow $300 to purchase a motorbike for her grocery business as transportation to bring products from the wholesaler back to her house.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her grocery business as transportation

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Sut Samut start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Oytuta

texts.ru:
Oytuta A. is 53 years old. She is married, has 3 children and a community college education. Her husband is disabled, her son works in Russia and her daughters help her with the business.

Oytuta decided to go into food sales because she is the sole family provider and carries all the family responsibilities. Prior to getting involved with MLF MicroInvest she used to borrow from local money lenders at very high interest rates. After joining MLF MicroInvest in 2002 she obtained a loan to increase her sales, hoping that this will also help improve her standard of living. She used the loan to add more variety to her inventory and to increase her stall space. Most importantly she was also able to get an improvement in her standard of living. Oytuta would like to use the next loan to open another stall/trading point.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Атоева Ойтута – 53года. Замужем, мать троих детей, образование среднее. Муж инвалид, сын в России на заработках, дочери помогают матери в торговле. Поскольку все жизненные заботы были на её голове, она решила заняться торговлей продуктами питания. До получения займа в МЗФ «Микроинвест» она брала в долг у местных кредиторов под большие проценты. В 2002году узнав о программе, она решила получить займ, и тем самым расширить товарооборот и улучшить уровень жизни. После получения займа она увеличила ассортимент, расширила место деятельности и самое главное улучшила уровень жизни. В дальнейшем планирует открыть еще одну торговую точку.

loans.use: To open another trading stall/point

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en:
Prossy is a 47 year-old married woman caring for six children, two of whom are her brother's. She has a business cutting timber outside of Kampala. After she cuts the timber, she replants seedlings so that the land can become reforested. In total, she has six employees. With hand saws, they fell the trees again by hand and then saw the trees length wise into plank lumber.

Once the trees have been converted to lumber, she takes the lumber to Rubaga. There, it is used to make rough tables and chairs. She has been in business for seven years and has been receiving loans since 1998.

She plans to use a loan to hire transport for the lumber. Transportation must be paid for in advance. In addition, she plans to start farming some of the land. She would like to plant sweet potatoes and root crops. She would then sell those in the city, using the transport. On the land, she hopes to start planting sweet potatoes and root plants.

She loves the land. Her dream is to one day have a tractor and even a truck for transport.

loans.use: To hire transport for her lumber.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Mrs. Kim K., age 43, raises and sells pigs to earn $2 per day. Her husband climbs palm trees to collect sap to boil and produce palm sugar, which he sells in the market, making $5 per day. They have three children, one who sells rice and foodstuffs at the market and two who work as blacksmiths making $2 per day each.

Mrs. Kim K. would like to borrow $750 to purchase a rice hulling mill so that they can start a business separating the rice from the hull for rice farmers and thereby increase their income.

loans.use: To purchase a rice mill to start a rice hulling business

payments.comment:
Thanks to the successful of her business that is why she can pay off the loan a head of time.
She would like to say thank deeply from her heart to all lenders.

loans.name: Peang

texts.en:
Mrs. Peang S., age 47, works in the market selling mortars and pestles for grinding food, earning $3 each day. Her husband makes the mortars and pestles that she sells, carving them out of blocks of stone. They have six children, two who work in Thailand earning $8 per day together, two who assist their father in producing the mortars and pestles, and two who are students.

In order to expand their business and meet client demand, Mrs. Peang S. would like to borrow $600 to buy additional stones and materials needed to produce the mortars and pestles. Her husband is pictured here producing a mortar.

loans.use: To purchase stone and raw materials to supply the mortar and pestle business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.en:
Maimuna is a widow with five children, all of whom are in primary school. In the village of Kayunga, Uganda, she is an active member of the Zununula Women’s Loan Group. She has a well-run hardware store and wishes to add cement and other building materials to her inventory.

Mai has had experience in borrowing since 2005. She has had no problem in paying back any of her loans. In that time, she has been able to acquire both an apartment and a building.

Her future plans are for her children to have the best in education. She also wants to continue to grow her hardware store to make it the best in Kayunga.

loans.use: To add a line of cement and other building supplies to her hardware store.

loans.name: Kit

texts.en: Mrs. Kit P., age 46, can earn $3.60 per day selling vegetables in her community. Her husband is the chief of the village, making $1.60 per day. She has two children; one is a field worker and the other is unemployed. In order to maximize her business size and meet her clients’ needs, she would like to request a loan of $500 to purchase more fruits to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more fruit to expand her inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Hasifa

texts.en:
Hasifa is a young, 29 year-old woman who is married with five children. Two of her children are in secondary school and the others are in primary school. She runs a small hotel in Kayunga, Uganda and has been in business for seven years.

She is a very hard-working woman and a committed, trustworthy member of the Bwetyaba Development Group. Her first loan was for $175.00 USD and she did not have any problem paying it back on-time.

She is experiencing an increase in customers at her hotel. She would like to use the money from a new loan to buy additional furniture and hotel equipment. The community would also benefit from the tourism business that guests would generate from shopping and restaurant businesses.

loans.use: To buy more furniture and equipment for her hotel

loans.name: Nasibahon

texts.ru:
Nasibahon R. is 39 years old and is married with four children. Her children all go to school. She has a community college degree and her husband works as a welder.

Nasibahon started selling fish 5 years ago. After finding out about the MLF MicroInvest program and joining it she got a loan to increase her sales. She was able to do this and also to add new customers and get a larger trading space. Today her assets have doubled in value. She would like to use the new loan to move into wholesale trade and be a fish supplier for other towns and vendors.

Translated from Russian by Olga Espira, Kiva volunteer.

Рахимова Насибахон –39лет. Замужем, мать четверых детей, образование среднее. Муж работает сварщиком, дети учатся в школе. Начала заниматься торговлей рыбами 5лет назад. Узнав о программе МЗФ «Микроинвест» она решила получить займ и увеличить товарооборот. После получения займа она увеличила товар, расширила место, приобрела много новых клиентов. Сейчас её активы увеличились в два раза. В будущем планирует перейти на оптовую продажу и поставлять товар в другие города.

loans.use: To move into wholesale  trade

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha has a very popular beauty salon in Bukuwro, Uganda that she has run for the past four years. She wishes to buy a new hair dryer and to restock her business with cosmetics and braids.

She is a very cordial person with a great deal of business sense. Aisha is also very hard-working and she hopes to make her business the best hair salon in Bukowto.

loans.use: To buy a new hair dryer and to restock her cosmetics with her loan

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms. Nguyen Thi H., a 48 year-old woman who lives in Nghi Trung commune, Nghi Loc always has passion on her job. Her small stall with groceries such as duck eggs, garlic, onion, spice, cereal products plays an important part in her whole family income. H. has been a member of TYM for 6 years, with the total loans increasing from 75USD at the beginning to 325USD at the present. She said TYM’s policy helps her learn how to save and spend reasonably. Her income is about 3USD per day. Besides the repayment to TYM, each month she earns 60USD. Her two children have grown up, one becomes a teacher and the other becomes a soldier. H. thinks she will continue this job for another 15 years. Now she is applying for a 325USD loan to buy more groceries for her stall.

Translated from Vietnamese by Phuong Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, một phụ nữ 48 tuổi sống tại xã Nghi Trung, Nghi Lộc, luôn cảm thấy yêu thích công việc mà mình đang làm. Quầy hàng nhỏ với các mặt hàng như trứng vịt, hành, tỏi, gia vị ... đóng góp một phần quan trọng về thu nhập trong gia đình chị. Đây là năm thứ 6 chị tham gia Quỹ Tình thương, số vốn được vay đã tăng từ 75 USD ở vòng đầu lên 325 USD thời điểm hiện tại. Chị nói cơ chế hoàn trả của Quỹ giúp chị biết cách tiết kiệm và tính toán hợp lý mỗi khi chi tiêu. Thu nhập hàng ngày khoảng 3 USD, ngoài các khoản phí hoàn trả cho Quỹ mỗi tháng chị thu về khoảng 60 USD. Hai con chị đã trưởng thành, một làm giáo viên, một đi bộ đội. Chị nghĩ mình sẽ còn tiếp tục làm công việc này trong 15 năm nữa. Hiện chị đang xin vay 325 USD đầu tư cho việc mua hàng.

loans.use: buy groceries, etc duck eggs, garlic, onion, spice, cereal products ...

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Mrs. Ou L., age 42, is a market vendor selling grocery products to earn about $3 per day in revenue. Her husband is a taxi driver earning about $5 per day in revenue. They have four children, two of whom are students and two of whom are married and no longer living at home.

In order to expand her business to meet customer demand, Mrs. Ou L. would like to borrow $1000 to purchase additional grocery products for her stand. She will also use part of the loan to finance the purchase of another taxi for her husband to drive, to replace the old car he was using. She is pictured here with one of her daughters.

loans.use: To buy additional products for her grocery business and purchase a new taxi for her husband's business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn Thị V. is 32 years old. She lives in Nghi Liên, has 3 children aged between 1 and 10. She cultivates her land of 7/10 acre but her main work is raising the pigs. This type of work is very popular among the peasant women. She started participating in the fund in 2002. For her first loan, she only applied for 75 USD since she did not have any experience with the loan system. Her profit raises after each round of loan so does the loan amount. It goes from 75 to 100, 150, 200 USD. Ever since she participates in the fund, her husband spends more time taking care of the children to free her up so she could qualify for the loans. This time she is requesting a loan of 375 USD to buy a cow and pig food.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chị Nguyễn Thị V., 32 tuổi, xã Nghi Liên là mẹ của 3 đứa con từ 1 đến 10 tuổi. Ngoài làm 7 sào ruộng, công việc chủ yếu của chị là chăn nuôi lợn. Đây là công việc khá phổ biến với người phụ nữ nông thôn Việt Nam. Để có nguồn vốn mua lợn giống, thức ăn chị tham gia Quỹ Tình thương từ năm 2002. Thời gian đầu chưa quen với việc hoàn trả của Quỹ chị chỉ xin vay 75 USD. Công việc kinh doanh thuận lợi, chị tăng dần mức vốn vay lên 100, 150, 200 USD/vòng vốn. Từ khi chị tham gia vay vốn, anh Đặng Hồng Lan chồng chị dành nhiều thời gian chăm sóc các con hơn để vợ có điều kiện thực hiện dự án. Bắt đầu vòng vốn thứ 5, chị V. xin vay 375 USD để mua thêm một con bò cùng thức ăn cho lợn.

loans.use: buy a cow and pig food

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Olga Abilio

texts.pt:
Olga is a single mother with 2 children. She lives in a neighborhood nearby Xai-Xai. She works in a public institution as a clerk. She also works on her small businesses. She joined the credit program in 2006. She invested previous loans in her business. Now Olga wants to take this loan and buy construction material to build a home. Her children are both in school and she is able to support them.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Olga e mae solteira e tem 2 filhos.Ela vive num bairro periferico da cidade de Xai-Xai. Ela trabalha numa instituicao publica como escrituraria. Para alem de trabalhadora ela faz pequenos negocios. Ela entrou para o Programa de credito em 2006.Os emprestimos anteriores ela investiu no seu negocio. Porque o negocio esta a correr bem, ela quer agora tomar um outro emprestimo para a compra de material de construcao para poder construir a sua propria residencia.Anteriormente ela vivia numa casa de pau a pique.Os seus filhos ja vao a escola e ela consegue sustenta-los.

loans.use: to buy construction material

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Her husband passed away 4 years ago, Ms Nguyễn Thị Hiệu must work hard to raise her 2 young children alone. It's difficult to provide 3 meals a day for her family. It's even more difficult to provide her children with an education. She works as a laborer in the field, raises pigs and sells goods at the market. All these works require time and money to invest. Ms Hiệu received her first loan from TYM fund in 2001. With 75 USD, she bought a pig. She made a small profit from selling the pig but it was a motivating factor for her to continue. Not only TYM fund provides capital for people like her to invest in a business, it is also a source of moral support to her in difficult times. Ms Hiệu is a very active member of the fund, she encourages other women to enroll in the program. She is the representative of the women group for TYM fund branch 10 in Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An. She's requesting a loan of 500 USD to repair the pigsty, buy a few pigs and buy goods to resell at the market.

Trnaslated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer

Chồng mất từ cách đây 4 năm, một mình chị Nguyễn Thị Hiệu phải lao động để nuôi hai con nhỏ. Lo được đủ ăn hàng ngày đã khó, lo cho hai con được học hành đầy đủ càng khó hơn. Ngoài công việc đồng áng, chị Hiệu còn dành thời gian cho việc chăn nuôi, chạy chợ. Những công việc này ngoài thời gian còn đòi hỏi phải có vốn đầu tư. Chị bắt đầu với 75 USD vay của Quỹ Tình thương năm 2001 đầu tư cho chăn nuôi lợn. Số lãi ban đầu tuy không nhiều nhưng đủ tạo niềm tin cho chị Hiệu vay tiếp những vòng sau. Quỹ Tình thương không chỉ cung cấp vốn mà còn là chỗ dựa tinh thần cho chị mỗi khi gặp khó khăn. Không những vay vốn làm ăn chị còn tích cực vận động những chị em có nhu cầu vay vốn tham gia Quỹ. Chị hiện đang là cụm trưởng của Quỹ tại chi nhánh 10 Nghi Lộc, Nghệ An. Chị vừa làm đơn xin vay 500 USD để sửa sang chuồng trại, mua vài con lợn và mua hàng bán ngoài chợ.

loans.use: to repair pigsty and buy some pigs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for TYM Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty runs a small bar in Kayunga. She is a very experienced business person who first started her career by making a local beer called Malwa. But now, she hopes to expand her inventory of beer and beverages at her bar. In time, she hopes to expand her business further and then become a wholesaler within her trading center.

She has used loan services successfully since 1997 and has had no problem repaying them.

loans.use: To expand her inventory of beer and sodas

loans.name: Te

texts.en: Mrs. Te L., age 47, is a widow and works as a farmer earning $1 per day. She has one child who no longer lives at home. She plans to increase her income by starting a clothing sales business. She would like to request this loan of $500 to finance the purchase of clothes from the wholesalers to resell to people in her area for a profit. She plans to save the money to be able to take care of herself in her old age.

loans.use: To start a clothing sales business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Khim

texts.en: Mrs. Khim Y., age 58, is a widow who earns $1.50 per day selling grocery products in front of her home. She has five children, two of whom are students. One runs a food stall earning $10 per day in revenue, and two are married and not living at home. In order to maximize her business growth and meet customer demand, Mrs. Khim Y. would like to request a loan of $700 to purchase more beverage and grocery products to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more beverage and grocery products to expand her inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence N. is 27 years old, married and has one small child. She operates a small, eight-room hotel with her husband. She keeps it clean, but the building is old and worn. The rooms are large but quite sparse with merely a bed and one chair. In addition, she runs a small secretarial service. She has a computer and printer. She and her husband have been in business for the past seven years and has received two previous loans.

This is a very industrious woman with lots of ideas for improving her hotel. She dreams of converting the garage into a small dining room where she can serve breakfast to her guests. She and her husband had a small bakery in the past, but the worker absconded with the funds and almost left them destitute, so they decided to focus on the hotel and secretarial service.

With her loan, she plans to buy 15 pairs of bed sheets for the hotel. Step by step, she will continue to improve her hotel and the lives of her family.

loans.use: To buy an additional 15 pairs of bedsheets for her hotel

loans.name: Florencia Luanica

texts.pt:
Florencia is not married but she lives with the father of her 4 children. She joined the credit program in 2006. Florencia sells Tapioca, peanuts and shellfish. Before she joined the program Florencia used to buy these products in small quantities, but now she is able to acquire merchandise fore resell in bulk and at a better price. Her business is growing and she is able to help with home expenses, buy books and clothes for her children.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Florencia nao e casada mas vive maritalmente com um homem de quem tem 4 filhos. Ela entrou para ao programa de credito em 2006. Ela venda mariscos,tapioca e amendoim. Antes de entrar para o programa adquiria estes produtos em pequenas quantidades. Mas desde que comecou a tomar dinheiro emprestado ela passou a adquirir os produtos para a revenda em sacos. O negocio dela esta a prosperar aos poucos.Ela ja consegue comparticipar nas despesas da casa, assim como comprar livros e roupa para os filhos.

loans.use: Increase Inventory

loans.name: Sou

texts.en: Mr. Sou S., age 32, manages a rental house in his community, earning $2.60 per day. He is not yet married. He would like to request this loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike and start a business as a moto-taxi driver to generate additional income.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a moto-taxi business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma N. is a 37 year-old widowed woman. She has four children and cares for two of her sister's children. Caring for the children of other members of your family (brothers or sisters) who have died (often from AIDs) is the norm in Rubaga.

Fatuma has a small home with a very low doorway that requires one to step down and duck in order to enter. In her house (with approximately dimensions of 10’ x 10’), with no apparent light except for the weak rays from the doorway, she collects a large stack of T-shirts piled on a chair. She walked to the market and bought 40-50 of the shirts, which she will now hang up and sell outside of her home. She has been doing this for two years now and goes to the market a couple times per month.

With her loan, she hopes to buy T-shirts in larger quantities. She hopes that she can buy a “bale” which would be 1,000 T-shirts. The loan will be sufficient for her to buy her first bale. This is exciting for her. She has been planning for some time how the increased quantities and the reduced cost per item will help her buy clothes for her own children.

(If you would like to learn more, please check out the Fellows Blog: The Women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To buy t-shirt in larger quanities, bales, to reduce the cost of each shirt

loans.name: Belinda Fabiao

texts.pt:
Belinda lives with her husband and 4 children. Belinda and her husband work butchering and selling pork meat. She joined the program in 2005. In the beginning she had joined with a group but she is now borrowing on her own. The business is doing well, with the income from the business she supports her family and sends her children to school.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Belinda casada vive com o marido e com os filhos. Ela tem 4 filhos.Ela e o marido fazem abates e vendem carne de porco na residencia.Belinda entrou para o programa de credito em 2005.Nessa altura ela tomava emprestimo inserida num grupo. mas agora resolveu tomar o emprestimo individual. O negocio esta a correr-lhe bem Com os lucros ela consegue pagar a escola para os seus filhos e comparticipa nas despesas da casa.

loans.use: Buy more animals

loans.name: Amelia Judas

texts.pt:
Amelia lives and runs her business in Inhambe. She has a small grocery store. She lives with the father of her 3 children. She joined the program in 2006. She is now in the 5th stage. In her store, Amelia sells various products. She is now able to pay for the schooling of her children. If the business continues to do well, she plans on improving her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Amelia vive em Inhambane e e la onde desenvolve o seu negocio. Ela tem uma pequena mercearia.Ela e mae de 3 filhos.Vive maritalmente com um homem que e o pai dos filhos..Amelia entrou para o programa em 2006.Agora esta no quinto ciclo.Ela vende produtos diversos.O negocio dela esta a prosperar.Ela ja consegue pagar sem dificuldades a escola dos seus filhos e comparticipar nas despesas da casa. Se o negocio continuar a correr bem ela pensa melhorar a sua residencia.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Josefa

texts.pt:
Josefa is married and mother of 5 children. She lives with her family in a neighborhood called Cumbana in Inhambe. She joined the credit program in 2006, and is now in the 6th stage. With this loan she wants to increase her inventory. She sells various products including shellfish and basic products. Her business is growing. With the income from the business she has been able to buy a freezer, pay for the schooling of her children and help with home expenses. In the future she plans on improving her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Josefa e casada e mae de 5 filhos. Ela vive com o seu marido e os seus filhos num bairro suburbano chamado Cumbana em Inhambane. Ela entrou para o programna de Credito em 2006 e ja esta no sexto ciclo. Com o valor do emprestimo ela quer comprar mais produtos para poder rechear a sua pequena mercearia. Ela vende produtos diversos de primeira necessidade e vende tambem mariscos frescos. O negocio dela esta a crescer.Com os lucros conseguiu comrar mais um congelador para guardar os mariscos. Com os lucros ela consegue pagar a escola dos filhos e comparticipar nas despesas da casa. se tudo correr bem no futuro ela pretende ampliar a sua casa.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Perciosa Jose

texts.pt:
Perciosa lives in Maxixe. She is married and has 3 children. She has just joined the credit program. Perciosa sells sodas, with this loan she plans on buying other products to resell in her small bar. If the business continues to do well she wants to help with home expenses, and help her husband pay for the schooling of her children.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Perciosa vive na Maxixe. Ela e casada e tem 3 filhos. Ela esta a entrar pela primeira vez no programa de credito. Ela vende refrigerantes. Com o valor do emprestimo pretende compraroutro tipo de produtos para vender no seu pequeno bar.Se o negocio correr bem ela pensa comparticipar nas despesas da casa. e tambem ajudar o marido a pagar a escola dos filhos.

loans.use: Increase and diversify inventory

loans.name: Judite Joao

texts.pt:
Judite is the single mother of 8 children. She joined the credit program this year, and she is now in the second cycle. With this loan she plans on buying more charcoal in order to keep up with the demand which is growing. Her business is doing well, and she doesn't have as many problems as she had before providing for her children. In the future she plans on building an improved house.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Judite tem oito filhos e mae solteira.Ela vive sozinha com os seus filhos. Esta no segundo ciclo. Ela entrou para o programa ainda neste ano.Com o dinheiro do emprestimo ela quer aumentar o numero de sacos de carvao para poder satisfazer a todos os seus clientes, pois que a procura esta aumentando.O seu negocio esta a prosperar. Ja nao sente tantos apertos como sentia anteriormente para poder sustentar os seus filhos. Se tudo continuar a correr bem ela pretende no futuro construir uma casa melhorada.

loans.use: Increase inventory

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 34 years old and has four children. She has a restaurant that she has operated for the past eight years. The restaurant consists of two outdoor cooking pots heated with charcoal. She has a small wood frame hut with a corrugated roof for her clients to sit under. Her customers include school children and passer-bys.

Her first loan was for $30.00 USD, using the funds to buy cooking oil, wheat flour and milk daily. With this new loan, she plans to add to her menu tea, chapatas, and meals with sauces. She has been receiving loans for several years and she is always able to make her payments.

loans.use: To buy more tea, chapatas and sauces for her restaurant

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is quite an amazing woman. She is 46 years old and has five children - with one at the university and two who will also attend shortly.

She earns a living by running a small tailoring business. She has two foot-run machines at her house, and one that she uses on the street where she can be close to the day's traffic. Everyone bids her a 'hello' as they pass her sewing station. She is well-known in the community and makes school uniforms for all the children using colorful scraps of material.

Edith's first loan was in 1997 for $30.00 USD. She plans to use her new loan to buy more material and to pay the school fees for her children. Her dream is to one day have a retail shop and to continue her tailoring. She is a joy.

(If you would like to learn more check out the Kiva Fellows Blog: The women of Rubaga)

loans.use: To buy more material to make school uniforms.

loans.name: Mafalda Chambuleluan

texts.pt:
Mafalda is a single mother of 4 children. She joined the credit program this year. She plans on using this loan to invest in her business. She hopes that her business does well, so she can improve her family's diet and send her children to school without struggling as she does now. In the future she also hopes to improve her home.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Komatsuzaki Fraga, Kiva Volunteer.

Mafalda e mae solteira e tem 4 filhos. Ela esta entrando pela primeira vez no programa de credito. Ela quer usar o dinheiro para reforcar o seu negocio para poder angariar mais clientes.Ela pensa que se o negocio correr bem ela podera no futuro melhorar a sua dieta alimentar, os seus filhos poderao estudar sem grandes dificuldades como tem sido ate agora.mais tarde ira pensar em melhorar tambem a sua residencia que ja e muito velha e e feita de colmo.

loans.use: Increase invetory

loans.name: Faridah

texts.en:
Faridah is a gentle woman who cares for eight children, including dependents. She has a small restaurant consisting of two outdoor cooking pots heated by charcoal. Behind the pots is a rough hewed lumber hut for her guests to gather. Inside are two tightly placed tables about the size of picnic tables. A corrugated roof is overhead.

Besides the entrance, the only access to the outside is a window from which she can pass the food from the cooking pots to the guests. This is also the sight where the women's lending group meets weekly. She was instrumental in starting the group.

Faridah has been receiving loans since 1996 - her first for $30.00 USD. Her restaurant is well-received. She has many regular clients. There is a machine shop nearby and the workers regularly visit. Also, many school children stop by.

She hopes to use her next loan to buy food for the restaurant. One day, she would like to start-up a retail store and to rear some chickens. (if you would like to learn more check out the Fellow Blog: The Women Of Rubaga)

loans.use: To buy more items for sauces, and foodstuffs for her restaurant.

loans.name: Fatu

texts.en:
Fatu, a mother of seven children, sells items such as sugar, chicken stock cubes, and tomato paste in the open-air market in Makeni town of Sierra Leone. Her husband does irregular and temporary work that does not guarantee a flow of income for the family. Fatu’s business is therefore the main source of income for her family.

With her previous loans, Fatu made a profit and has invested a portion of that into farming. Fatu’s aim is to have family food from the farm so that the business income can be mainly used for the children’s school fees and medical expenses. Fatu is presently requesting a loan of US$ 250 to expand her business.

loans.use: Continue to expand her grocery business in the Makeni market

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.es:
ZENAIDA is 30 years old, with four daughters. She is going to rent a location and she will establish a cafe where she will serve traditional snacks of the community: tacos, empanadas, chalupas, drinks, cakes, etc. The business will operate every afternoon and the principal customers will be the people of the area. She is part of the solidarity group called Perla 1. With this loan she will invest in the purchase of kitchen utensils, tables, chairs, and the basic materials to start her business.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

ZENAIDA tiene 30 años, cuatro hijas. Ella va a rentar un local y establecerá un comedor donde vendan antojitos tradicionales de la comunidad; tacos, empanadas, chalupas, bebidas, tortas, etc., el negocio estará funcionando todas las tardes siendo sus principales clientes gente de su localidad. Forma parte del grupo solidario llamado Perla 1. Con su préstamo invertirá en la compra de utensilios de cocina, mesas, sillas y la materia prima para emprender el negocio.

loans.use: FOOD SALES

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
TERESA will open a grocery store in her home, where she will sell: corn, sugar, salt, oil, cookies, sweets, etc. Her principal customers will be the women of her community. She is part of the solidarity group called Perla 1. With her loan she will buy products to establish her business and she will order shelves made where she can place her products to display them. She is 51 years old, has five children, and her earnings will be used to support herself since her children already have their own families.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

TERESA abrirá una tienda de abarrotes en su casa, en donde venderá; arroz, azúcar, sal, aceite, galletas, dulces, etc., siendo sus principales clientes las mujeres de su comunidad. Forma parte del grupo llamado Perla 1. Con su préstamo comprara productos para el abastecimiento de su negocio y mandara hacer estantes en donde colocara sus productos para exhibirlos. Ella tiene 51 años, cinco hijos y sus ganancias serán para su mantenimiento ya que sus hijos tienen su propia familia.

loans.use: GROCERY STORE

loans.name: Alie

texts.en: Alie is thirty-five years old and married with one child.  He is engaged in the selling of cosmetics in the outskirts of Makeni town.  He raised his initial capital from working as a casual laborer,but has added to his capital with loans from SMT and increased his stock.  His business is the only source of income for his family.  With the profits, he has managed to meet his family expenses.  He plans to expand the business and is therefore requesting a loan of $250.

loans.use: Increase his cosmetics inventory available for sale

loans.name: Alimamy

texts.en: Alimamy is 45 years old and sells cigarettes, sweet biscuits and canned foods at the market in Makeni. He is married with four children. He would like to develop his business into a big store in the future. He said his previous loan has allowed him to move his business one step ahead.  Alimamy is requesting to borrow US$ 350 for this purpose.

loans.use: Expand his business to eventually operate a grocery store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maria  Elena

texts.es:
MARIA ELENA is 42 years old and single. She is an artisan, she embroiders tablecloths, napkins, shawls, and cushions, and she brings them to a tourist beach six hours from her home to sell them. She rents the location where she sells. She is part of the solidarity group called PerL. 1. With her loan she will invest in the purchase of thread in bulk, in a variety of colors. She will pay the rent on her location, which will enable her to continue selling there, and she will also buy finished merchandise from the women of her community.

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

MARIA ELENA tiene 42 años, soltera. ElL. es artesana borda manteles, servilletas, chales, cojines y los lleva a vender a una playa turística ubicada a seis horas D. su comunidad y renta el local en donD. venD.. Forma parte del grupo solidario llamado PerL. 1. Con su préstamo invertirá en L. compra D. hilo al por mayor en su variedad D. colores, pagará L. renta del local el cual le permitirá seguir vendiendo ahí y también comprara mercancía terminada a las mujeres D. su comunidad.

loans.use: HANDICRAFTS

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 38 years old and married with three children. She started her business when she was 22 years old, but it was destroyed during the civil war in Sierra Leone. She picked up again after the war but at a very small scale due to lack of capital.

With previous loans from Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), Fatmata has been able to generate additional income to help her pay the family's expenses. She is requesting an additional loan to further expand her business. Fatmata says that she would like to purchase more stock for Christmas sales to earn a good income from the increased sales she expects during the holiday season.
